column2: The bridge across the Frith of Tay, which fell on Sunday night, was regarded as a triumph of engineering skill. It was the longest structure of the kind in the world.

James Smith, alias Howard, whose story before Justice Flammer, on Christmas Eve, of a consumptive wife and starving child in a miserable attic at No. 172 Mulberry-street, to get broad for whom he had been driven to steal, enlisted the sympathy of the charitable public, appeared in the District Attorney's office yesterday morning to give bail for his appearance when called upon, many prominent citizens having volunteered to become his surety.

LONDON, Dec. 29.--The train on the North British Railway, which was precipitated into the Frith of Tay by the breaking of the Tay bridge, left Edinburgh Sunday afternoon at 4:15 o'clock, and consisted of four cars of the third class, one of the first class, one of the second class, and a brakeman's van.

AUGUSTA, Dec. 29.--It is the general opinion that Gov. Garcelon will not submit to the Supreme Court the questions propounded by exGov. Morrill. The Republicans will be prepared for this, and will present the question through a majority of the members of the last Senate, as it is thought such proceedings would conform with the law.

PARIS, Dec. 15.--Diamond robberies are by no means rare incidents in the French capital; few months go by without the record of some successful burglary in this line, sometimes from the shop-window of a jeweler, quite as often from some private house, whose mistress has not been sufficiently discriminating in the choice of her intimates.

From the 1st of January, 1879, up to the close of business yesterday there were reported at the Bureau of Vital Statistics 28,224 deaths. The total number of deaths in 1878 was 27,008; in 1877, 26,203, and in 1876, 29,152.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 29.--The lobbies of the County Court-house and the halls leading from the main entrance to the doors of the Superior Court room were so densely packed at 2 o'clock this afternoon, with persons anxious to gain admission to the Hayden trial, that the services of a court officer were necessary to keep open a passage for those entitled to admission.

BOSTON, Dec. 29.--Gen. B.F. Butler has stated to a reporter his views on the situation in Maine. He contradicts the statement that has been made in some quarters that he has given Gov. Garcelon and Council legal advice on the course they have taken.

Goddefroy Sons, the Hamburg merchants, who suspended business some time ago."

LOS PINOS AGENCY, Col., Dec, 28. The commission adjourned yesterday, to meet on Dec. 29 at Cline's Ranch, on Cimarron River, 25 miles south-east of the agency, there to await the arrival of the prisoners. Gen, Hatch and escort left here in a drizzling rain at 4 o'clock this morning.

MADRID, Dec. 30. As the King and Queen of Spain were driving through the gate of the royal palace this evening, a young man, dressed as a workman, fired a shot from a revolver at the royal carriage, but his aim was bad, and nobody was hurt. The ball has since been found, and weighs one ounce. It passed close to the head of one of the royal footmen.

BOSTON, Dee. 30. Early this morning a young girl appeared in the doorway of a building on Hamilton-place, a quiet way just off from Tremont-street, and beckoning excitedly to an expressman standing near by, urged him to hasten to a certain doctor and implore him to come to her rooms at once, as her mother had been shot and was dying. The man went on the errand and the physician came.

Arrangements for the reception of Mr. Charles Stewart Parnell, the Irish agitator, have been completed by the Executive Committee. Liberal contributions were received yesterday toward the necessary expenses of the reception. Gilmore's Garden was secured for Sunday evening next, when Mr. Parnell will deliver an address on the Irish land question, and several prominent citizens have been invited to be present to hear Mr. Parnell's views on the subject now agitating Ireland.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Dec. 30. The old trouble in the Methodist Episcopal Church of this town again became the theme of general comment to-day when tho news reached here by the early morning train that the Quarterly Conference, at Orange, had reversed the verdict of the ecclesiastical court lately held here, and reinstated Dr. Sedgwick R. Osmun as a member in good standing of the Methodist Episcopal Church of Morristown.

Attorney-General Schoonmaker, in speaking of the discontinuance of the Kingsley-Keeney suits, said, this evening, that the reservoir case had been discontinued because the Court of Appeals had rendered a decision, in a cross-action, which made it useless, and merely an unnecessary expense to Brooklyn, to continue the action for the people. AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 30. The Committee on Public Safety, of this city, called upon Gov. Garcelon this forenoon and had a long interview. The committee consisted of Gen. Henry Boynton, the Hon. Joseph Nye, ex-Gov. Conner, Joseph A. Homan, Major J.D. Myrick, and Amos Wilder. They informed the Governor that they represented the people of the town, and would cordially join with Mayor Nash in his recommendations and suggestions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 The position taken by the President in his recent Message in relation to polygamy, the efforts made by the friends of Gov. Emery, of Utah, to procure his reappointment, and those of his opponents to induce the appointment of another candidate, have brought prominently before Congress and the country the Mormon problem, tho solution of which, in the opinion of many thoughtful men, presents difficulties of great magnitude.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 30. The Republican State Committee met here to-day, at the Continental Hotel, for the purpose of naming a date for the holding of the State Convention.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30. Gen. Grant received callers this morning until 10:30, and afterward walked about the city with Gen. Beale until 2:30. He then lunched at Gen. Beale's residence. All the members of the Grant family were present with the exception of the General's married daughter, Nellie. At 5:30 P.M., Gen. Grant and party left for Richmond in Col. Scott's private car "President."

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 30. The end of the Hayden trial is now rapidly approaching. At the opening of the afternoon session of the court today the defense rested, and the rebuttal was begun by the State. Much testimony of importance was introduced by both sides during the day.

A large audience assembled at the Democratic mass-meeting to-night, the City Hall being packed; there were many ladies in the galleries, and a large number of prominent Democrats were upon the platform. Sullivan C. Andrews presided, and opened the meeting with a brief speech, introducing Congressman Ladd.

ALBANY, Jan. 4.--The Speakership fight was over at midnight on Saturday, when the withdrawal of Mr. Skinner and Mr. Baker, and the tender of their support to Gen. Sharpe, decided the contest in favor of the Ulster member.

CHICAGO, December, 1879.--If it be true of men that "blood will tell," the success in life achieved by Elihu B. Washburne, of Illinois, who was a farmer's boy, a printer's apprentice, who has been a lawyer, statesman, and diplomat, and who is to-day fore ...

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.--It has been announced that Chairman Cameron, of the Republican National Committee, has appointed C. I. Filley, of Missouri; John C. New, of Indiana, and Powell Clayton, of Arkansas, a sub-committee to act with the Chairman and Secretary in making all the local arrangements for holding the convention in Chicago.

NYACK, N.Y., Jan. 4.--A series of thefts have recently occurred in several of the shoe factories in this village, which have, until now, been supposed to be the work of traveling thieves. A discovery was made in the week just past, however, which indicates that at least a portion of the stealing was done by persons residing here.

FLORENCE, Dec. 16.--We are in the midst of a "cold snap" such as the combined memories of three generations of the "oldest inhabitants" of Italy cannot recall. They are compelled to go back to the latter part of the eighteenth century to find its parallel.

WATERVILLE, Jan. 4.--Gov. Garcelon spent the day here. He was called upon this evening by a reporter, who asked if he had received the opinion of the Supreme Court, to which he replied that he had not, and that he had not been in Augusta since 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon.

A muffinman has been brought into court and fined for ringing his bell. Such a proceeding may at the first blush seem high-handed, for why, it might be asked, is the muffinman not to ring his bell, while the costermonger may yell and Punch go piping down the street? The question is a natural one ...

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Dec. 28.--The reader of biographies will remember that Theodosia, the only daughter of Aaron Burr, was never heard of after her voyage to visit her father in New-York, and that hitherto all speculations as to her death and disappearance have been fruitless.
ST. PETERSBURG, Jan. 4.--An emphatic official denial is given that the establishment of a Regency in whole or in part is contemplated.

FERNANDINA, Fla., Jan. 4.--Gen. Grant and party arrived here this morning at 11 o'clock, from Savannah, by the inside route steamer City of Bridgeton, after a delightful trip. The day was beautiful, and the streets were crowded with people to welcome the guests.

During the last year 19,367 orders were issued by the Board of Health, as against 12,190 in 1878. Seven thousand one hundred and eightynine seavengers' permits were issued in 1879, an increase of 2,563 over the preceding year.

Henry W. Longfellow will be 73 years of age on the 27th of February proximo. The public schools will celebrate the occasion with brief sketches, addresses, and recitations pertaining to the poet. The following correspondence is of interest in this connection:
M. Gounod has just composed a new work, a "Miserere" for four voices and solo. The musical library of the late M. Roger, the famous tenor and teacher, is to be sold this month in Paris.
WASHINTON, Jan, 5.--Capt, William J. Volkmar, Fifth Oavalry, is ordered to Fort Leavenworth, Kan., to report for duty as Aide-de-Camp on Gen. Pope's staff.

Contrary to the annual custom, the old Board of Aldermen went out of existence yesterday without the flourish of complimentary resolutions and the indiscriminate pelting of minute-books which marked the closing hours of their predecessors.

HARTFORD, Jan. 5.--The two leading Democratic papers in Connecticut have justified the alleged strict construction, but really illegal outrage, in Maine, the New-Haven organ directly approving it, and the Hartford journal giving it favor by malicious retorts to Republican denunciations.

Last Tuesday afternoon Mrs. Mary Lunney died at No. 1,902, Cuyler-street, aged 103 years. She was born in Lancastor County, Ponn., on the 12th of March, 1776, and resided is this city for 40 years. She was married in Lancaster County in the year 1802 to Patrick Lunney, who died about the years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--The feature of the new rules of the House which is likely to elicit most discussion is that which provides that the River and Harbor Appropriation bill shall be formulated by the Commerce Committee, and when reported to the House shall be printed and referred to the Committee on Appropriations.
"The Tourists in a Pullman Palace Car" was revived at Haverly's Theatre last night. This piece was very popular when it was first brought out here a few weeks ago.

The Rev. William McAllister, Pastor of the Cornell Memorial Church, in Seventy-sixth-street, near Second-avenue, and a prominent member of the New-York East Conference, Methodist Episcopal, died on Saturday evening at about 8 o'clock, in his residence at No. 243 East-Eighty-second-street, after a brief illness.

LONDON, Jan. 5.--A dispatch from Kandahar says: "The leader of the Herati troops escaped, after their defeat, to Ghorian, near the Persian frontier, where he is collecting a force to attack the Kabulis, who are virtually besieged in Herat.
PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 2--A contract for the construction of the Texas and Pacific Railway westward from its present terminus, at Fort Worth, to El Paso, was signed on Wednesday.

The present series of revivals at Wallack's is of the most eclectic character. There is a long jump from "She Stoops to Conquer" and "The Liar" to "A Scrap of Paper," "Home," and "My Awful Dad," and "London Assurance" is the bridge between the two extremes.

It has been repeatedly suggested that if a canal should be cut through the Isthmus of Panama without locks, as M. DE LESSEPS proposes to cut his canal, the Gulf Stream would improve the opportunity to slip through the canal and into the Pacific Ocean.

To the Honorable the Common Council: The efficiency of our Municipal Administration de pends largely upon the power of the Mayor to hold the heads of the several departments to a strict accountability.

The Mayor does not appear to have made a very liberal use of his power "to keep himself informed of the doings of the several departments," or, at least, if he has, he has failed to give the Aldermen and the public the benefit of his experience.

The Brooklyn Board of Aldermen held its first meeting is 1880 yesterday. The chamber and the approaches to it were densely crowded for hours before the meeting, although it was known quite early in the day that the Democrats had secured Smith and Powers, the two renegade Republicans who sold out their party last Summer, and who have since voted with the Ring men.
According to appointment, the special committee selected by the Grain Trade to demand relief from the operations of the cental system had a conference with the Board of Managers yesterday.

By a fire at the Turn Halle, in East Fourth-street yesterday morning, three persons lost their lives by suffocation, and two were killed in attempting to escape, by falling from a window. Four persons were seriously injured.

LONDON, Jan. 5.--The North German Lloyd steamer Hansa, Capt. Danneman, from Now-York, for Bremen, previously reported as having gone ashore on Terschelling, an island in the North Sea, leaked so badly that the crew was obliged to leave her, and was landed by tags. The steamer is beginning to sink. Strong efforts are being made to lighten her.

The first of what it is proposed to make an uninterrupted series of "opera balls" on the plan of those given annually by the stockholders of the European Academies of Music, took place at the Academy last evening.
FERNANDINA, Fla., Jan. 5.--Gen. Grant and a portion of his party were in the streets early this morning, and walked for some time about the city.
AUGUSTA, Jan. 5.--The members of the Legislature are now assembling, and the position of affairs is freely discussed on the Republican side, but the Democrats are extremely reticent.

Juilliard against Thomas S. Greenman, generally known as the loyal tender case, which now stands No. 779 on the calender.

The men employed by the Celluloid Manufacturing Company, at Ferry and Ashbridge streets, Newark, resumed work yesterday morning for the first time since Christmas. The main building abuts on Ferry-street, and runs --one section of it--160 feet southward, another section 100 feet southward.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--Among the cases to be considered by Congress is that of Col. James Belger, a retired veteran, who enlisted in the Army in 1832 as a private, and who was in service until November, 1863, taking part in the Mexican war and the war of the rebellion.

Public interest in the affairs of the broken Grocers' Bank was a greatly increased yesterday by the arrest, late in the day, of Mr. J. Lloyd Haigh, the wire and steel merchant, on the serious charge of forgery.

It looks very much as if we are to have two of them together, and as there is only a bench for one, it is plain as the nose of Slankenbergius, that if Charley Gilman and Ned Barnum try to occupy it at the same time, somebody will have to be sat down upon.
HARTFORD, Jan. 5.--When the Legislature which was elected in November, 1878, dissolved in March last, it adjourned to meet on Tuesday, Jan. 6, 1880, and will therefore come together to-morrow.

At the monthly meeting of the Brooklyn bridge Trustees, yesterday, an important report was submitted by Trustee Isaae Newton, who was requested to test seven of the suspenders of the bridge in the machine in the United States Arsenal, at Watertown, Mass.

ALBANY, N. Y., Jan. 5.--The Republican Senate caucus met in the Senate Chamber, and organized by electing Judge Robertson Chairman, and Senators Mills, of Herkimer, and Pitts, of Orleans, Secretaries.

ALBANY, Jan. 5.--With the arrival of the earliest trains to-day this city filled up with a throng of office-seekers almost innumerable, and the hotels are more abundantly patronized than they have been for many months.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5.--A new term of the Court of Appeals will commence on Tuesday, Jan. 13, 1880, which will be a motion day. The following is a list of the first 50 cases on the new calendar: No. 1--McCarney vs. The People; No. 2--Ryan vs.
A eable dispatch announces that President Prado, of Peru, has been deposed and that Don Nicolas de Pierola has been made supreme chief of the Republic in his place.
Judge Gildersleeve swore in the Grand Jury for January yesterday. Mr. Oliver K. King, of No. 84 Broadway, was chosen foreman.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 5.--There has been little change in the Senatorial outlook to-day, unless it be that the friends of Taft and Matthews are a little more buoyant.

The Khram Spaseetelya, or Temple of our Saviour, at Moscow, is now rapidly approaching completion. The building was begun so far back as 1833, and was designed in commemoration of the French expulsion from Moscow.

The Constitution of Maine prescribes that the Governor and Council shall examine the returned lists of votes cast at the election for Senators and Representatives, and issue summonses to such persons as appear to be elected.

Fire broke out in the planing mill of Ira E. Doying, Nos. 191 and 193 East Seventy-sixthstreet, at about 6 o'clock last evening, and an hour later only the walls of the building--a three-story brick structure--were left standing.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Jan. 5.--Jesse James is dead, George Shepard's shot having done the work. His wife is at the house of Mrs. Samuels, mother of the James boys, in Clay County.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5.--In the United States Supreme Conrt to-day, a decision was rendered in the three following-named suits: No. 81--The United States, appellant, against Henry Clamorgan and others.
In July, 1865, John Lavin, an illiterate Irishman, then dwelling in this City, deposited $300 in the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank, and in the following January $100 additional.

At the election last November, Mr. James R. Angel was elected Justice of the District Court in the annexed district, the jurisdiction of which embraces tho whole of the Twenty-third and Twentyfourth Wards. The term of office is six years, commencing with the 1st of January.
The registered Woman's Committee in Boston have issued an address explaining the results of the first experiment in women's voting, which was for school officers.
ALBANY, Jan. 5.--Gen. George H. Sharpe, of Kingston, Ulster County, was tonight chosen unanimously, by the Republican caucus, to be the Speaker of the Assembly of 1880.

The Commercial National Bank of Chicago drew a check for $254 50 on the Bank of NewYork, of this City, in favor of Wirt Dexter, on Jan. 4, 1879. Dexter indorsed the check to the order of Mrs. Amelia H.D. Godman, and mailed it to her.

The third of the series of chamber-music concerts by the New-York Philharmonic Club was given last night at Chickering Hall to an audience composed largely of musicians and the most cultivated class of amateurs.

The funeral services of the late Rev. William McAllister took place at the Cornell Memorial Church, East Seventy-sixth-street last evening. Trappings of woe were everywhere visible. The altar-rail and the front of the galleries were shrouded in black, and black folds, caught up by rosettes, extended above the several entrances to the building.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 6.--A Coroner's jury to day returned a verdict charging Dr. J.H. Liverpool with being accessory to the death of Mrs. Caroline Krauss, who died recently from criminal malpractice. The Doctor is held to await the action of the District Attorney.
PARIS, Jan. 6.--An official dispatch received at the Chilian Legation here announces that Gen. Daza, President of the Republic of Bolivia, has been deposed, and has fled.

AKRON, Ohio, Jan. 6.--The Atlantic and Great Western Railroad was sold at noon today by Gen. J.H. Devereux, of Cleveland, the Special Master Commissioner, under the foreclosure proceedings, in Summit County, of the Court of Common Pleas, and similar courts in Pennsylvania and New-York.

Linden Township, Union County, N.J., a suburb of Elizabeth City, is in a state of excitement over complications in which their late Tax Collector has become involved. Joseph James, an insurance agent doing business in Elizabeth, but residing at Roselle, had been the Township Collector for five or six years prior to March of last year. Then Jeremiah Richards was elected to the position.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--The House Committee on Commerce to-day decided to resume the consideration of the Inter-State Commerce bill on Tuesday next, and to hear arguments on the part of the leading trunk lines of railway on that day.

The Republican General Committee of Kings County met last evening in Vineyard Hall, corner of Fulton and Jay streets. The attendance was large. Dr. Watts, the newly-elected Chairman presided. ALBANY, Jan. 6.--The new Senate convened at 11 A.M., in the room designed for the Court of Appeals, which will continue to be occupied until the completion of the Senate Chamber, in the south wing of the new Capitol. All the Senators were present except Mr. Woodin.

PANAMA, Dec. 27.--The Legislature of the State, now in session, has passed a law increasing the commercial contributions, or the tax paid by the merchants of the city, by 25 per cent. When the measure was first proposed the merchants unanimously petitioned the Assembly against the passage of the bill. The anual meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held last evening in the society building, Second-avenue and Eleventh-street, Mr. Frederie de Peyster, the President, occupying the chair. The annual report of the Treasurer gave the total receipts for 1879 from various sources as $23,088 44, and the expenditures as $20,972 85, leaving a balance on hand of $2,115 49.

The January Term of the Passaic County Courts opened yesterday, at Paterson, N.J. Col. Bird W. Spencer, Treasurer of the New-York Lake Erie and Western Railroad, is Foreman of the Grand Jury. The most important business for the Grand Jury is the investigation of the murder of John Nyman, at Passaic, last November.

Our correspondent at Buda Pesth telegraphs to us a terrible story, or rather the tragic close of a terrible story, which reaches him from Sophia. Sixty of the Mohammedan refugees, whom the Bulgarian Government had refused to admit into their former homes, have lately, he says, died in the open fields from cold and starvation.
PORTLAND, Me., Jan. 6.--There appeared in this afternoon's press dispatches a letter signed by Thomas B. Swan, of Minot, saying that he would not act with the Fusionists.
The VICE-PRESIDENT laid before the Senate a petition of the American Social Science Association, relative to international coinage and the metric system. Referred to the Committee on Finance.
LONDON, Jan. 6.--The fund instituted by the Lord Mayor of London for the relief of the popular distress in Ireland now amounts to 5,000.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 6.--Depositions in the libel suit of Carlotta A. Patti against the PostDispatch, of St. Louis, have been taken here the past two days for the defense, and have disclosed a good deal of evidence against the sobriety of Patti on the occasion of her concert here a short time ago.

Outside of the release of J. Lloyd Haigh on bail, there were few developments in the Grocers' Bank failure yesterday. The clerks were quietly at work getting affairs into shape for Receiver S.V. White, and there were few visitors during the day. Cashier Periam said it was true that Mr. Haigh was a self-confessed forger, and this assertion was also made by the Cashier of the Market National Bank.
William Stockmeyer, who, on Monday, jumped from the ferry-boat Northfield off Governor's Island, died yesterday at the Chambers-Street Hospital.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 6.--The Hayden trial entered upon its thirteenth week to-day, with every indication that it will last two weeks more. The day was devoted to the introduction of odds and ends of evidence of more or less interest, and at its close the counsel for the State announced that their rebutting evidence was all in.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--Two singular documents were introduced in the Senate to-day. One, which came through Mr. Conkling's hands, is the petition of Isaac I. Covert and others, of Ovid, N.Y., for aid in establishing the cultivation of the tea plant in Texas.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--Among the bills introduced in the Senate to-day were three from Mr. Vest in relation to the compensation of United States Marshals and Deputy Marshals, Clerks of United States courts, and United States District Attorneys.
LEADVILLE, Col., Jan. 6.--James Bradbury, a well-known prospector and miner, reached this city this evening from the Ute Reservation, and tells a terrible story of his privations and sufferings.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 6.--The caacus of to-night nominated Gen. Garfield for United States Senator by acclamation, and without the formality of a ballot. Nothing was done in the House yesterday to develop the opinions of the members concerning the adoption of the proposed new rules for the government of that body. But it is evident that the old contest is to be renewed soon, with new complications.

The fifth American Chess Congress commenced its "grand tournament" yesterday in the upper hall of No. 60 West Fourteenth-street. The floor was covered with a large carpet of chessboard designs, smaller designs of the same character, in patch work, hung against the walls, as well as pictures of chess congresses and famous chess players.

PITTSTON, Penn., Jan. 6.--While Mrs. Mary Hook, of this place, was absent from her home, this morning, her little child, whom she had left looked up in the house, was burned to death, his clothing having become ignited while playing with the fire.

A short time ago Mr. Benjamin Fitch, of New-York, gave to the Charity Organization Society of Buffalo, under a few simple and proper conditions, the house on Swan-street near Michigan, in former years the residence of the late Lucius H. Pratt, the property extending southerly and then easterly to Michigan-street in the form of an L. leaving a lare vacant lot, 75 by 110 feet, at the corner, which was not included in the gift.

The examination in the case of Patrick R. Burns, a private detective, who is charged with perjury on complaint of Richard H. Wilde, of New-Orleans, was commenced yesterday, before Justice Morgan, at the Jefferson Market Police Court.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 6.--The attempt to influence Mr. Voter, of Farmington, who was counted in as a member of the Legislature, to abandon his position in refusing his certificate of election, has proved a failure. He refuses to participate in the proceedings of a Legislature to which he was not chosen.

Mr. SCALES, of North Carolina, Chairman of the Committee on Indian Affairs, reported a resolution directing that committee to investigate and report upon the origin of the recent outbreak of the Ute Indians, and authorizing it to send for persons and papers.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 6.--The Texas and St. Louis Railway Company have petitioned Congress for a reduction of the specific duty on steel rails from $28 to $10 a ton.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 6.--To-morrow the Maryland Legislature will begin its biennial session at Annapolis. The Legislature is composed of 82 Conservative-Democrats, 26 Republicans, and 2 Independents. The chief interest at the opening of the session centres around the election of a United States Senator to succeed W. Pinckney Whyte, whose term will expire March 4, 1881.

Paris, Dec. 22.--I have not yet found half a dozen persons of the same way of thinking about Thursday night's festival. The newspapers, which got it up, are all in its praise; not so the crowd who, like myself, paid for their tickets and had, therefore, a right to criticise.

The fatal disaster at the cellnoid works on Monday continued to attract general attention yesterday, the scene of the explosion being visited by thousands. Coroner Woodruff yesterday impaneled a jury. After viewing the bodies, they adjourned until Friday morning at 10 o'clock.

LONDON, Jan. 6.--The Daily Telegraph vouches for the trustworthiness of a communication, dated Koenigsberg, Dec. 31, asserting that the distribution of the Russian Army shows a striking convergence toward the western portion of the Empire, and that Russia's effective forces are being increased in far greater proportions than can be justified by the object of filling up the vacancies left by the late Russo-Turkish war.

The night freight train on the Long Branch Division of the New-Jersey Central Eailroad left Sea Girt, 12 miles below Long Branch, on Monday, at midnight. The train consisted of an engine, tender, and 22 cars, under charge of Conductor Knox.

Gen. Prado, ex-President of Peru, arrived in this City last evening, en route to Europe. When he left Lima on the 18th of December last, to visit Europe for the purpose of arranging certain important interests of his country, he placed the Government in the hands of Gen. La Puerta, the Vice-President, and the other members of the Cabinet.

Dr. W. LAUDER LINDSAY is probably better acquainted with animals than any other scientific person now living. He has spent years in their society, and has been admitted to the confidence of the humble earth-worm and the friendship of the most aristocratic dogs.

The Commissioners of the Sinking Fund met yesterday and organized for the present year by re-electing Mayor Cooper President and Mr. William H. Dikeman Clerk. Recorder Smyth, who by virtue of his office is a member of the board, was present for the first time.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y. Jan. 6.--A meeting of milk-producer of Orange, Sullivan, and Sussex Counties was held at Middletown to-day to form an organization for mutual protection, and to secure better prices for milk. Over 250 delegates were present, representing most of the important stations in the three counties.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Jan. 7.--The Georgia Central Railroad stock, which on Tuesday evening was quoted at 79, went up to 93 this morning, closing this evening at 89. There is a general expression of satisfaction at the leasing of the road.

The twelfth annual ball of the Old Guard was given in the Academy of Music last night. It was one of the most successful and enjoyable in the series. The Old Guard was organized in 1869, by the consolidation of the Light Guard, organized in 1826, and the City Guard, organized in 1833.

A TIMES reporter called upon Commissioner Campbell yesterday, in relation to the statement of the Council of Political Reform that the Department of Public Works had asked the Board of Apportionment for $2,344,500 for the present year, that the board allowed only $2,049,600, and that the Council proposed a reduction of $640,000 from the amount asked.

The two upper floors of the Young Men's Christian Association's Building are occupied by a large colony of artists. How large the colony is was evidently a surprise to the greater number of the crowds that thronged elevator, halls, and studios yesterday afternoon and evening.

COLUMBUS, Jan. 15.--A reception was given to Gen. Garfield, United States Senatorelect, in the Capitol last night. Gen. Garfield was introduced by Gov. Foster, and, after some hand-shaking, made a speech, in which he referred to the gratification felt at his election and this reception.

The impressive burial service of the Protestant Episcopal Church was hold, yesterday morning, in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, over the body of Ellen Lewis Herndon Arthur, the wife of Gen. Chester A. Arthur.

The newly-organized Washington and West Washington Market Men's Protective Association held their second meeting yesterday in Smith McNell's Hotel. VIENNA, Jan. 15.--Special dispatches from Pesth state that serious disturbances occurred in that city on Tuesday and Wednesday in consequence of the duel between Baron Maithenyi and Herr Verhovay, member of Parliament, in which the latter was fatally wounded, and that further trouble is feared.

ENGLISHTOWN, N.J., Jan. 15.--The residence of the Rev. A.P. Cobb was entered by burglars on Sunday night while the clergyman and family were asleep, and robbed it of a lot of silverware, jewelry, and clothing valued at $800.

Jerry R. George, a New-Jersey Central Railroad conductor, was married in Newark a few days ago eo Miss Addie S. Ellis. Both are residents of Dover, N.J., and the marriage was performed in the house of George's brother. Miss Ellis was expected to marry Mark Roy, of Hunt's Mills, Sussex County.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--In 1836 the United States was in a remarkable financial condition, with from $40,000,000 to $50,000,000 in the Treasury, and no debts. Under the leadership of Calhoun and Clay it was proposed to distribute this money among the States.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 15.--The Committee on Ways and Means to-day considered Mr. Wood's Refunding bill.

A policy-holder in one of the New-York life insurance companies expresses alarm at a decline of 25 per cent. which has occurred in the rate of dividend paid to him. He regards it as evidence of an impairment of resources that cails for vigorous action on the part of policy-holders whose experience is akin to his own.

ALBANY, Jan. 15.--Immediately after the assembling of the Senate this morning the private secretary of the Governor made his appearance with the first installment of Mr. Cornell's appointees to office. Rhorer, Cashier of the Savings Bank of Louisville: It is the custom of this, as well as all, Louisville banks, the law of Kentucky so requiring, to publish a semi-annual statement of its condition.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 15.--The final argument in the Hayden trial was concluded by Mr. Watrous this evening. Mr. Waller occupied the entire forenoon with his summing up for the State. Mr. Waller's address was hardly an argument, but rather an eloquent portrayal of the State's view of the case.

AUGUSTA, Me., Jan. 15.--The Fusion Senate met at 10 o'clock, and took a recess until 3 o'clock without transacting any business. In the afternoon the remonstrance of Isaac T. Quimby was presented against James A. Locke, holding a seat at the board as Senator from Cumberland, and claiming Locke's seat. This was referred to the Committee on Senatorial Votes.

The preliminaries connected with the addition of a new building to the Astor Library, which have been quietly, but rapidly, carried forward within the last few weeks, were completed yesterday. The will of the late Frank Leslie was opened and offered for probate yesterday in the Surrogate's Court, on the petition of his widow, Miriam F. Leslie. BEEFSTEAK STEWED WITHOUT WATER.--Get three or four pounds of rump steak, cut about an inch thick: put an ounce of butter in a frying-pan large enough to hold your steak, and let the butter melt without browning: wash the steak quickly in cold water and put it in the frying-pan, covering closely.

There was certainly no lack of variety in the programme of the Symphony Society's third concert, which was given last night at Steinway Hall, and was preceded by a public rehearsal on Thursday afternoon.

The concert to be devoted to Mr. Arthur Sullivan's works will be given at Steinway Hall on the 31st inst. Among the artists engaged are Miss Henrietta Beebe, Miss Winaut, Mrs. Fairlamb of Washington, and Mr. Courtney.

LONDON, Jan. 1.--Bond-street yesterday was a strange picture of mud and wealth, of discomfort and luxury. The new wood pavement was flooded in the rain that poured down in torrents. Carriage after carriage dashed through the wet, pulling up at the covered entrance to the Grosvenor Gallery.
The cause of the explosion on the steamer Greece, at the wharf in Hoboken, Friday afternoon, which killed two men and jeopardized the lives of over a hundred others, has been discovered.

At 10:20 A. M. yesterday it was known that the jury in the case of John Nugent, a Police officer of the Eighteenth Precinct, charged with complicity in the Manhattan Bank burglary, after 18 hours' deliberation, had agreed upon a verdict, and the arrival of Judge Cowing was anxiously awaited.
Mr. Davidge will not be a member of Mr. Daly's company after this week. He has been engaged by Mr. Hill to play with the latter's new company in "All the Rage."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--The salaries of District Attorneys and their assistants, as fixed by the bill recently introduced by Senator Vest, are as follows: Maine, Attorney, $2,000. New-Hampshire, Attorney, $2,000. Vermont, Attorney, $2,000.

At the general epiphany services of Calvary Church, at Fourth-avenue and Twenty-first-street, last evening, the Right Rev. Bishop Coxe, of the Diocese of Western New-York, made an appeal in behalf of foreign missions.
Seven deaths from measles were reported to the Health Department during the 24 hours ending at noon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 18.--At the election in the Second Congressional District of Florida in November, 1878, the opposing candidates were H. Bisbee, Jr., Republican, and Noble A. Hull, Democrat. The State Canvassing Board declared the election of Hull, and the Governor gave him a certificate.

AUBURN, N.Y., Jan. 18.--Public sentiment is about equally divided in reference to the alleged absconding of the Hon. Charles N. Ross. ex-State Treasurer. Many persons are slow to believe the numerous rumors afloat, because of the high social position Ross has always occupied in the community.

LEAVENWORTH, Kan., Jan. 18.--Ex-City Clerk Frederick M. Spalding, who has been on trial during the last week, and was found guilty of embezzlement in office, was sentenced yesterday to the State Prison for four years and six months.

Seeger is concerned--has become an event of some social prestige and moment, both by reason of the number of tickets disposed of in fashionable society, and of something beautiful in the design of the affair.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Jan. 19.--The failure of the Nashville and Chattanooga Railroad Directors to confirm the contract made with the Georgia Central Railroad Directors has caused a decline in the stock of the latter road, from 92 to 84.

The brig Excelsior, which arrived from Cape Haytien yesterday, with a cargo of logwood, brought the crew of the schooner Lizzie Morris, which was run down off Cape Hatteras on the night of Jan. 7 by an unknown bark, which immediately proceeded on her way, regardless of the cries for help from those on board the injured vessel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19.--The Senate Committee on Privileges and Elections met this morning and took up the Kellogg case. It was announced that the committee had decided not to admit as evidence the first volume of testimony taken by the Potter committee, which Mr. Merrick on Saturday asked to have incorporated into the record.

BOSTON, Jan. 19.--A shocking murder was committed to-night in Bowker-street, near Sudbury, in this city, the person murdered and the assailant being women and sisters.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Jan. 19.--The Democratic caucus to-night balloted for a nominee for United States Senator. On the first ballot R.L. Gibson received 49 votes; John McEnery, 37; Leuis Texada, 9; Don Caffrey, 8; H.R. Scott, 2; and L.A. Wiltz, 1. On the second ballot Gibson received 53; McEnery, 38; scattering, 16.

The report of the Managers of the Society for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents, for the nine months ending Sept. 30, 1879, has been published. It shows that the number of children in the House on the 1st of January, 1879, was 903; that there had been received during nine months of the year 1879, 470; making a total of 1,373, that there have been indentured and discharged during the nine months 600.

MONTGOMERY, N.Y., Jan. 19.--The Ulster County express train, from Kingston, ran over and killed Edward Culligan, near Binnewater, on the Wallkill Valley Road, this morning at 7:30. The engineer whistled to warn him off the track, when he turned and looked back at the approaching train, and then walked leisurely on.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19.--The goods of Stettauer Brothers were this morning sold in lots under the hammer, and realized 53.44 cents on the dollar. The creditors were then allowed to bid for the whole in bulk, and A. Lowenthal secured the whole stock at the rate of 58 cents. Lowenthal was an employe of the firm, and it is understood that he will ship the goods to kansas City for sale by his father.

LONDON, Jan. 19.--The steamer Saratoga, Capt. Sundberg, from New-York Jan. 15, arrived here to-day. The steamer stopped, backed, lowered a boat, and searched an hour for his body, but did not recover it.

JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 19.--No result was reached in the caucus to-night. Before the voting began the name of Gen. Walthall was withdrawn, and that of Gen. George was proposed. Five ballots were taken, and on the last-- the fortieth ballot--Barksdale stood 52, Singleton 52, and George 32. The Senatorial question comes before the Legislature to-morrow.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Jan. 19.--Gen. Grant and party arrived here this afternoon from St. Augustine, and will start at 9 o'clock to-morrow for Cedar Keys to take the steamship Admiral for Havana. The party will tarry an hour or two at Key West on its way.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Jan. 19.--The news of Gen. Eli H. Murray's appointment as Governor of Utah was received here with great satisfaction. CITY OF MEXICO, Jan. 10.--Elder Thatcher, a Mormon apostle, and his colleagues are working energetically in the interest of the Utah Saints. They are baptizing converts daily, and are publishing an organ, called the Gazette Del Desereto.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 19.--This morning, at 11 o'clock, Judge Bradford opened the session of the United States Circuit Court, to take action in regard to the appointment of United States Supervisors of Registration.

SCRANTON, Penn., Jan. 20.--Springville, a small village near Montrose, Susquehanna County, was the scene of a terrible tragedy today, in which Eugene Hawley was shot by a man named John Richards. The men had a quarrel in the house of Richards, who ejected Hawley.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., Jan. 19.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Permanent Exhibition was held here to-day, and the present Directors were re-elected to serve for the ensuing year. A motion to close the exhibition on Sunday was defeated. The financial reports show a balance of cash on hand of $13,000. The admissions last year were nearly half a million.

The accident which occurred on the Metropolitan Elevated Railroad yesterday morning was the most remarkable recorded in the history of the elevated railway system of this City. An engine dragging a single passenger car containing about 20 persons, and running at a speed of 35 miles an hour, leaped the track and went plunging over into the street below.

SCRANTON, Jan. 25.--This was a sombre Sabbath in Scranton. Robert Johnson, a young man who was shot in the street last night, about midnight, died at the hospital this morning at 4 o'clock. Coroner Daniels held an inquest, and, with Drs. Lackey and Heath, made a post-mortem examination.

Grant here place no reliance whatever in the statement telegraphed from Washington to the effect "that before the meeting of the Pennsylvania State Convention next Wednesday week an authoritative declaration would be made which would withdraw the exPresident from the field as a contestant for the Presidential nomination."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26.--The importers and manufacturers of sugar will be heard tomorrow by the Committee on Ways and Means, in relation to proposed modifications in the present rates of duty on that commodity.

Yesterday was the last day of the grand tournament of the fifth American Congress. Ten players were entered, and each player played with every other, two games, on two successive days. Ninety games were played altogether, the tournament lasting 18 days.

PLATTSBURG, Jan. 26.--Paul Shoppy, who was shot at Willsboro Point stone quarry by Richard M. Elliott on Jan. 16, has died from the effects of the wounds inflicted by Elliott, who has been locked up in the Essex County Jail to await the action of the Grand Jury. Shoppy and Elliott were both employed in the stone quarry, and had some trouble about their children.

LONDON, Jan. 26.--The Right Hon. John Bright, in his speech at Birmingham on Saturday, suggested that Parliament should appoint a commission to go to Dublin, with power to sell the farms of landlords, when they are willing to sell, to tenants who are willing to buy them, and to advance three-fourths of the purchase money therefor, the principal and interest to be repaid in 35 years.

LONDON, Jan. 17.--"Society is on the 'op hagain," to quote the remark of a cabman I heard talking to another one night this week opposite a fine house in Mayfair, "and things is a-lookin' hup." The storm of snow and wind which visited this City yesterday was one of the fiercest of recent years. Beginning far to the southwest, the storm centre in the past 48 hours has moved up from the Gulf of Mexico, taking in the States to the east and west of the Alleghanies, paasing over Now-York City and the New-England coast and lower lakes, and disappearing to the north-east in the Gulf of St. Lawrence.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 4.--Enoch Rasp, William Austin, and Thomas Flanigan pleaded guilty, at Newcastle, to-day, to an attempt to fire the Steam-boat Hotel, in this city. Had the indictment charged attempt at arson, their crimes would have been capital, but as the word was omitted, they escaped with two years' imprisonment and $500 fine.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5.--Although not unexpected, the death of the Hon. Adolph E. Borie, this morning, caused great regret here. Childs, in company with Gen. Grant and family.

The twenty-seventh annual ball of the Liederkranz Society, which took place in the Academy of Music last evening, was fully as largely attended as the famous ball given by the same society last year. The crush on that occasion surpassed anything, ever before known in the history of masked balls in this City.

LONDON, Feb. 5.--The weather to-day was fine. The royal procession, preliminary to the opening of Parliament, took place in accordance with the programme already announced. The Queen arrived at the House of Lords at 2:10 o'clock this afternoon. Upon receiving a copy of the speech from Lord Cairns, the Lord High Chancellor, her Majesty handed it back to him, and, as usual, Lord Cairns read the speech. The ceremony lasted 15 minutes.

The thirteenth annual report of the State Board of Charities, transmitted to the Legislature Feb. 5, summarizes the work of the board for the past year as follows: Committees of the board have visited all the State institutions, including poorhouses, alms-houses, hospitals, orphan asylums, and asylums for the care of the insane and inebriate. The county poor-houses of the State number 56.

DAYTON, Ohio, Feb. 6.--Julius Radke was arrested last night charged with the murder of his child, an infant of 4 months. Another child, 6 years of age, was in the room, and testified to the crime.

MADRID, Feb. 6.--Official dispatches have been received giving further details of the recent hurricane in the Philippine Islands. Twenty-five vessels of various classes were wrecked, including four foreign frigates, and a large number of other vessels were damaged. Forty-six persons were drowned.

Marshall, Cashier of the First National Rank of Middletown, Ohio, has fled, leaving behind him letters to officers of the bank and his family, explaining that he is driven to flight by slander and black-mail. COLUMBIA, S.C. Feb. 17.--The unblushing effrontery of some of the officers who hold appointments under the Secretary of the Treasury to pack the State Convention with delegates favorable to their chief's nomination in the National Convention, has become a subject of general remark and much severe criticism at the State capital, among Democrats and Republicans.

The State of Massachusetts indulges in a remarkable number and volume of official reports. In the Board of Aldermen yesterday, the Committee on County Affairs presented a long report in favor of anthorizing the United States Heating and Power Company to lay pipes in the streets for the purpose of heating buildings, A resolution granting the privilege accompanied the report.

LONDON, Feb. 17.--The Mark Lane Express, in its review of the British grain trade for the past week, says: "The weather during the past week has been seasonable. The rain was not excessive, and plowing has actively proceeded. It is still feared that some Autumn-sown wheat has been frosted, as many fields where it should have appeared are nearly bare, and in many where it has appeared it is neither strong nor forward.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17.--There was another animated contest in the House to-day over the new rules, the point in controversy being the twenty-first rule, which relates to General Appropriation bills. Physically, she was more like a man than a woman; her shoulders being broad and her muscles well developed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22.--Among the latest publications received at the document-rooms for distribution are over 50 reports from the House Committee on War Claims against the allowance of as many claims.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22.--The House Committee on Post Offices have determined to move, to-morrow, to suspend the rules and pass a bill to appropriate about $1,500,000 to meet the deficiency in the Post Office appropriation caused by the unlawful action of Gen. Brady in increasing compensation for carrying the mails on star routes.
ROME, Feb. 22.--The Geographical Society has conferred a gold medal on Prof. Nordenskjold, the Swedish Arctic explorer.

A mass-meeting of piano-makers was held yesterday morning at the germania Assembly Rooms to take into consideration the strike of workmen employed at Hermann's furniture factory. Over 300 working men were present. The speaking was in German. Charles Siegel presided.

Our own table and game fish are so familiar that little need be said as to their merits; but a glance at the prices paid for certain kinds of fish during the Lenten and other seasons in olden times will perhaps be interesting. Standing at the head of the list was the red mullet, (Multus barbatus,) and nearly, allied to that prince of fishes, the brown mullet of Florida.

Mr. Le Grand B. Cannon has made a purchase in Florence which leaves him in possession of one of the finest pieces of sculpture finished by a modern Italian. The United States War Veterans celebrated the day yesterday by placing a laurel wreath on the head of the statue of Washington at Union-square and listening to a sermon by the Rev.Dr-Morgan Dix at Trinity Church. WASHINGTON, Feb. 25.--The House spent the entire day in discussing the bill to appropriate a sufficient sum of money to supply the deficiency in the star route mail service.

INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 25.--Reports have been received from all Congressional district meetings held to-day to select delegates to Chicago Convention.

Immediately afterward Gen. Arthur called the convention to order. E.M. Johnson, Secretary of the State Committee, began the calling of the roll.

The Count de Lesseps left the Windsor Hotel at 11 o'clock yesterday morning, with members of the American Society of Civil Engineers, to visit some of the great engineering monuments of New-York.

UTICA, Feb. 25.--The general prediction in regard to the result of the New-York Republican State Convention has been fully verified. The 70 delegates to the Chicago Convention who were chosen in Utica to-day are pledged absolutely to the support of Gen. Ulysses S. Grant, ...

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25.--In the Senate, today, Mr. WHYTE, of Maryland, asked unanimous consent to have the bill to remove the disabilities of James Monroe Heiskell, of Baltimore, taken up. Heiskell served in the Confederate Army when a boy, and, under section 1,218 of the Revised Statutes, is ineligible to appointment in the Army.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25.--A long bill, introduced in the Senate by Mr. Harris, provides for the construction of another railroad in and across the Indian Territory, from Fort Smith, on the Arkansas line, to Arkansas City, on the Kansas line.
An assignment for the benefit of creditors by Austin Carr to William H. Payne, was filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 26.--William Gair was found early this morning lying insensible at a forge in Corning's iron works. He had evidently been stabbed with a knife or some other sharp instrument, which made what probably will prove to be deadly cuts. Beside the stab wounds, Gair was brutally kicked and pounded.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26.--The Ninth Ward Working Men's Protective Club met last evening and organized a military company, 22 men signing the roll. Some very hot speeches were made at the meeting of the Ward Presidents, yesterday afternoon, previously referred to.

Mr. ROLLINS, from the Committee on Civil Service and Retrenchment, presented a minority report on certain memorials relative to alleged violations of civil service rules in the Providence Custom-house. Ordered to be printed and laid on the table.

The patrons of the Madison-Square Theatre were treated to a complete view of the mechanical operation of the double stage last evening. The upper stage was set for the first act of "Hazel Kirke," and the gasman was lighting the borderlights which surround the curtain.

DUBLIN, Feb. 26.--The Mansion House Relief Committee announce that the fund amounts to 78,035, and that grants have been made to date amounting to 39,004. A subscription of 465 from Springfield, Mass., is acknowledged.

OIL CITY, Penn., Feb. 26.--Extremes in prices and activity have been the rule in the oil trade of late. From comparatively low prices and sluggishness, the price dropped 16 points, and the transactions on the floor of the Exchange have been very large, and the excitement has been kept at fever heat.

ALBANY, Feb. 26.--The Assembly consumed this morning in disposing of bills on their third reading, and among the number passed was that to protect the streets bordering Central Park from the elevated railways. Speaker Sharpe announced the members of the joint committee on the revision of the laws relating to taxation.

A fleet of six European steam-ships, all of which had encountered more or less bad weather in crossing the Atlantic, arrived at Sandy Hook late Wednesday evening, and came up to their respective docks yesterday morning. The Labrador, of the French Line, sailed from Havre on the 14th with a large cargo and 647 passengers.

A lecture was delivered in Chickering Hall last evening, under the auspices of the New-York Academy of Sciences, by Prof. B.N. Martin, D.D., entitled "Proofs of Design in the Material Construction of the Globe." The lecturer remarked that the great argument of a creative design in the construction of the globe existed among the varying aspects of nature.

Who was the originator of the alleged joke that in leap-year women ask men to marry them, and where he was living, no one can confidently say. It is certain, however, that he lived many centuries ago, and was not a native of this continent.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 26.--An occasional call for a local convention to select delegates to one or the other of the two Greenback Presidential Conventions that have been called, reminds the public that a few fragments of the Greenback Party of Ohio are still alive, and that organizations are still in existence where the party is dead.

Yesterday M. De Lesseps had his portrait taken and made several calls on friends. In the evening he was the guest of the American Society of Civil Engineers at the theatre of the Union League Club. The hall was uncomfortably crowded, and many ladies were of the audience.

HONESDALE, Penn., Feb. 26.--The Delaware and Hudson Canal, as originally constructed, was much different from that of the present day. In 1828 it was 20 feet wide at the bottom and 32 feet wide at the surface, with a depth of 4 or 4 feet of water.

Some of the more hopeful members of the Democratic Party are saying to the Republicans, "Our dissensions are over; yours are just beginning." It would be difficult to find any dissensions in the Republican Party which will outlast the next National Convention.

The second of the series of organ and harp matinees at Chickering Hall, by Mr. and Miss Morgan, was given Wednesday afternoon, with the aid of Miss Winant. Mr. Morgan has every reason to congratulate himself on the success of his venture, for he had an unusually large audience, which almost completely filled the hall.

Thomery is a country retreat, and the retreat of one who has tried the first of cities and found it wanting. Though born at Bordeaux, Rosa Bonheur is almost Parisian by origin. She was brought up in the capital from her seventh year. She left it voluntarily in the maturity of her fame for this pleasant rural exile near Fontainebleau, where her genius finds what it loves above all things--repose and the contemplation of nature.

The fragments of the 38-ton gun, destroyed for experimental purposes in the bursting-cell in the proof grounds, Government Marshes, adjoining the Royal Arsenal, Woolwich, on Tuesday last, have all been recovered, and are found to number about 120 pieces. They have all been marked, and are being washed and arranged for inspection.

RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 26.--In the House of Delegates to-day, Ross Hamilton, the colored Republican member from Mecklinburg, demanded a committee to investigate the intimations made by the Whig this morning that improper means had been used to influence his action on the Debt bill.

LONDON, Feb. 26.--A dispatch from Constantinople to the Times says: "An aide-decamp to the Sultan has been taken into custody for complicity with the Greek who was arrested for having an infernal machine in his possession. The affair appears to have been a conspiracy against the Sultan's life."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26, 1880, The Treasury Department to-day pur chased 509,000 ounces of silver for the Mints at Philadelphia, New-Orleans, and San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The four Democratic members of the Senate Committee on Civil Service and Retrenchment, having submitted a majority report in relation to the investigation of the methods used in making removals and appointments in the Providence Custom-house, the three Republicans of the committee, Messrs. Rollins, Teller, and Baldwin offered a minority report to-day.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 26.--At a called meeting of the stockholders of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railroad this afternoon. President E.W. Cole gave notice that he would resign his position, which he could not consent to hold in a company which might not be able to afford him unquestionable authority to protect its interests.

The Seventeeth Assembly District Republican Association met last evening in the church edifice on Fiftieth street, near Eighth avenue. The meeting was called to order by the President, Col. Joel W. Mason. The large room was crowded with enthusiastic members, most of whom, it was quite evident, attended to manifest their satisfaction at the action of the party's representatives at Utica on Wednesday.
PARIS, Feb 13.--The German Reichstag opened yesterday, and, so far as goes the letter of the imperial speech, the Government is animated with the most pacific intentions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The action of the House to-day, in passing by a decisive vote the Post Route Deficiency bill, is in effect a vote of censure upon the Post Office Department for the loose and extravagant manner in which the star service has been conducted during the past two years.

Mrs. Emma Strecker died in this City, Feb. 18, 1879, possessed of an estate valued at about $500,000. She was a daughter of Mr. James Benkard, of the late firm of Benkard Hutton, and by the terms of a will made by her in October, 1878, she gave almost the whole of her vast estate to various charitable institutions.

DENVER, Col., Feb. 26.--The contest between the Western Union Telegraph Company and Mr. Gould's new telegraph company commenced here to-day. It has been announced that the American Union Company would supplant the Western Union Company on the Union Pacific Roads.

The festival and fancy dress ball, given by the Purim Association, in aid of Mount Sinai Hospital, at the Academy of Music, last evening, was one of the most largely attended of the season. In point of numbers and display the affair was fully up to the standard heretofore set by the association.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27, 1880. Both houses of Congress adjourned to-day until Monday. The receipts from internal ravenue to-day were $404,625 25, and from Customs, $1,091,505 83.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--In Mincing-lane the markets continue unsettled. Stocks are considerably larger than at the same time last year, owing to the small deliveries during the recent long period of depression. Sugar has fallen about 6d. per hundredweight. Refiners are taking only limited supplies.

The Assembly Committee on Cities, with Mr. VARNUM at its head, has entered upon the Herculean task of ascertaining how the thoroughfares of this City may be kept clean and the refuse from streets and dwellings disposed of in an effectual and economical manner, and in such a way that, if they will not do the most good, they will do the least harm.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The friends of the Military Land Warrant bill succeeded, after some very hard work in the Senate to-day, in rescuing it from entire destruction, and securing a postponement of the final decision until next December.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The Post Route Deficiency bill, which passed the House yesterday, directs that all additional compensation which has been ordered for increased speed in excess of $2,500 per annum, shall be discontinued, but that otherwise the star routes shall continue as they existed on Feb. 1.

On New Year's eve the dry-goods warehouse of mr. Mannasseh L. Goldman, at No. 61 Canalstreet, was entered and $7,000 worth of silks was carried off. Several previous unsuccessful attempts had been made to rob the warehouse.
OZARK, Ark., Feb. 27.--To-day, at 1 o'clock, James Howard Miller was hanged on the river bank below the town, in the presence of a large crowd of people.

The writ of habeas corpus was obtained for the purposes of two motions--one for a stay of execution of sentence pending an appeal to the General Term of the Supreme Court from the judgment of the General Sessions, and another for admission of Cowley to bail.

The widow, son, and daughter of William D. Fricke, who was found dead about two weeks ago, in New-Jersey, under circumstances leading to the belief that he had been murdered, filed objections to the will of the dead man which was recently offered for probate in the Surrogate's Office.
ALBANY, Feb. 27.--The annual report for the last year of the State Assessors, Messrs. James A. Briggs, John S. Fowler, and Sterling G. Hadley, has been prepared and sent to the Legislature.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27.--At the meeting here yesterday of the Executive Committee of the Trunk Lines Pool, on the subject of Eastern rates, the rates on hogs were reduced 5 cents per hundred, and rates to all New-England points were made the same as those to New-York. Rebates were abolished. It is intimated that further reductions in grain rates are not improbable.

PEORIA, Ill., March 4.--Jeremiah Webster and John Gutliff farmers living near Chillicothe, in this county, have had a dispute for several months about the division line between their respective farms. On Tuesday Webster started to build a fence on the disputed line, and Gutliff shot him, the ball taking effect in his head. Webster died of his wound yesterday morning. Gutliff was arrested.

ST. PETERSBURG, March 4.--The man who fired upon Gen. Melikoff yesterday, as he was alighting from a carriage at his residence, is a converted Jew named Mlodetsky, from Minsk, a town distant 430 miles south-west of St. Petersburg. He has been tried and sentenced to-day, and will be hanged to-morrow.

ATLANTA, Ga., March 11.--The Presidential canvass has fairly begun in Georgia. The Republican State Convention will be held in Atlanta on April 21. The Democratic State Convention will be called in a few days by the Executive Committee. It will probably meet early in May.

The dry goods store of Stephen McPartland, No. 643 Eighth-avenue, was burned out yesterday day morning, involving a loss of over $80,000. The store consisted of a three-story brick building, 25 feet front, the two lower stories of which had an extension, making the structure on the first and second floors 70 feet deep.

BOSTON, March 13.--The case of Nathan P. Pratt, Treasurer of the Reading Savings Bank, who was indicted upon 52 different counts for embezzlement of the funds of the bank was given to the jury to-day. A verdict of guilty on 29 counts was returned.

--That Greek art was carried to Bactria after the conquests of Alexander would be a natural and reasonable inference. A performance of "Faust" was listened to with attention and pleasure in the Academy of Music yesterday afternoon by an immense audience, in which, as a matter of course, the feminine element largely predominated. Observers of Lent have no reason to complain of the price of eggs. They are cheaper now than they were when the season began. Choice fresh eggs from near-by points may be bought in Washington Market at 20 cents per dozen, and those from remote parts of the State, the West, and the South are lower.

The sale of the Harper collection of paintings was completed, at Chickering Hall, last evening. The attendance was nearly as good as before, and, though the bidding did not lead off in very active style, it became very spirited as the sale proceeded. The prices realized were good, a trifle lower at the start than on the previous evening, but closing remarkably well.

ALLENTOWN, Penn., March 16.--Elisha J. Forrest, one of the oldest members of the Lehigh County bar, left here for Philadelphia last Tuesday, to pay some money to a firm in that city. MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 16.--The rains of the past five days have been very heavy, and the Alabama River has overflowed its banks. There are no reports of damage to any of the railroads centring here. It is now growing cold.

Dufur, of Marlboro, Mass., declared it a draw, neither side having gained a full fall. CALEDONIA, N.Y., March 22.--When the first settlers came into this part of the State, nearly a century ago, they found water gushing and boiling out of the earth where the quaint old village of Caledonia now stands. The volume of water was so great that it formed a wide, deep stream, which flowed away to the northward.

SOUTH AMBOY, N.J., March 25.--A tornado lasting 16 hours swept alone the southern NewJersey coast last evening, the velocity of which has not been equaled for many years. Much damage was done to young trees, and many large ones were blown down.

PANA, Ill., March 25.--A murder was committed yesterday afternoon in Clay County, four miles east of Louisville, in a small town on the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad. Newton Eaton was shot and killed by a man named Edmonds. The cause of the shooting was a quarrel over a money settlement involving a difference of 50 cents. Edmonds escaped, but is being closely pursued.

LONDON, March 25.--The ex-Empress Eugenie, traveling incognita as the Countess of Pierrefonds, and accompanied by Col. Sir Henry Evelyn and Lady Wood, the Marquis of Bassano and a small suite, embarked at Southampton to-day for South Africa, to visit the scene of the Prince Imperial's death.

OIL CITY, Penn., March 24.--Several months ago Robert G. Ingersoll lectured in this city, and among his audience was a resident named John Carroll. Some of the statements of the lecturer so worked on Carroll's mind that he became somewhat deranged. He was sent by his family to the Dixmont Insane Asylum, at Pittsburg.

Mr. Edwin Booth began last night, at Booth's Theatre, his brief farewell engagement, and a very large and notable assemblage was present to honor the eminent tragedian with its admiration and applause.

The Newark Annual Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church, which has been in session at Paterson, N.J., for a week past, adjourned yesterday afternoon. Biscoe, of Arlington, reported very briefly that the charges of immorality had been sustained, and they recommended that he be expelled from the Conference.

WASHINGTON, March 30.--The discussion of the bill for a world's Fair in New-York in 1883 was continued in the Senate to-day until the expiration of the morning hour. Mr. Edmunds proposed an amendment which provides that the corporation shall not exist after Jan. 1, 1885, and it was adopted.

The second trial of the suit of George Falkland against the St. Nicholas National Bank has closed in the Supreme Court. The case was before Judge Beach, and the result of the trial is in favor of the defendant corporation. There were some points of unusual interest in the case.

CHICAGO, March 31.--Burdette E. Patten, a private detective, who acted as a go-between in the case of bribing a juror, for which an attorney named Gribler recently was sentenced to six months' imprisonment, to-day received a similar sentence for contempt of court, for attempting to bribe a juror. The journeymen painters of Newark have notified their employers that from and after to-morrow they will demand $2.50 per day of 10 hours.

NOW-ORLEANS, March 31.--Gen. Grant and party arrived at Morgan City at 3:30 o'clock this afternoon, where they met the delegation from the City Council, and at once took the cars for this city. The party reached Algiers at 6 o'clock, and was greeted by a salute of 21 guns, fired by the Joseph A. Mower Post of the Grand Army of the Republic.

Mr. Mount felt perfectly well on Saturday evening last, when he dined at the Century Club with Smith Lane and a few friends. After dinner he complained of a slight chill, but when he left for home he was apparently in the best of health.

COMSTOCK, Mich., April 1.--Andrew Brown, a farmer living near here, yesterday ordered his daughter-in-law, who had been deserted by her husband, to leave his house. ATLANTA, Ga., April 1.--The political situation in Georgia has elements of encouragement to Republicans despite the top-heavy majority of the organized Democracy. The Independent Party is large and growing. At the last election it carried three Congressional districts, and would have captured a fourth (Atlanta,) if it had put out a good candidate.

ALBANY, April 1.--In the morning session of the Assembly to-day, the bill to preserve the purity of elections and prescribing the size of ballots was discussed at same length, and was finally defeated. ALBANY, April 7.--The majority and minority in the Assembly have got along very harmoniously together so far, principally because the minority has not endeavored seriously to obstruct business. A little friction was caused this morning upon the passage of some amendments to the charter of the City of Rome.

The New-York Methodist Episcepal Conference closed its labors yesterday and adjourned for one year. ALBANY, April 7.--The annual reports of the savings banks of Kings County have been made to the Superintendent of the Bank Department, showing their condition on the morning of Jan. l, 1880. The banks are 14 in number, 2 of which are closing, and have received no deposits during the year.

Roosevelt, No. 32 Pine-street, and the necessary preliminary steps were taken toward the immediate furtherance of their plan.

A patient at St. Vincent's Hospital, who is registered on the admission-book as George M. Jones, of Boston, committed suicide yesterday morning by shooting himself through the heart, under rather peculiar circumstances. It appears that at 3:15 A.M. One of the most important revolutions of the present time is the discovery beyond a doubt that Uric Acid in the blood is the cause of all rheumatic troubles. This acid causes a fermentation, which gives great pain to the muscles, stiffens the joints, and often blasts the entire life. The natural question is: "How does this poisonous uric acid get into the blood?"

The Coroner's inquest in the Paterson case of infanticide, referred to in THE TIMES yesterday, was resumed yesterday afternoon in the Court-house at Paterson. WASHINGTON, April 8.--The entire time devoted by the House to-day to the consideration of the Army Appropriation bill was taken up in discussing a point of order raised against the amendment to prohibit the use of the Army as a police force to keep the peace at the polls.

LIVERPOOL, March 27.--The public sales of wool in this town at intervals during the last two weeks have established the reality of American competition in a manner unexpected by English manufacturers. For the finer wools required for the manufacture of cloths, London is the market.

The sixty-fourth annual meeting of the NewYork Female Auxiliary Bible Society was held yesterday in the board-room of the American Bible Society. WESTCHESTER, Penn., April 9.--A premature explosion of several heavy blasts of giant powder in a rock cutting, where the Pennsylvania Railroad is being straightened, near Downington, occurred last evening. Twenty-five men were immediately in front of the blasts, but most of them escaped fatal injury. John Powers, the overseer, and Robert Taylor, a laborer, were killed, the former being frightfully mangled. Six or eight men were badly hurt, and several more sustained slight wounds.

Babcoek, which was recently argued before Judge Myers, at this place, is one of great importance to the people of North-eastern Pennsylvania. LONDON, March 31.--A trying week for painters, for patrons, and for artists' friends. All intending exhibitors at the Royal Academy, outside the privileged body of associates and academicians, must send their works to Burlington House to-day or to-morrow.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--The sub-committee of the House Committee on Pacific Railroads, at a meeting to-day, voted two to one against granting any extension to the Northern Pacific Railroad. The matter will come up in the full committee on Friday.

ALBANY, April 14--The third reading of bills was continued in the Senate this morning until the list was completed. Most of them were of local importance only. Judge Robertson, from the Judiciary Committee, made adverse reports on several bills that had been sent to his committee, including a concurrent resolution, offered by Senator Halbert, for an amendment to the Constitution, allowing women to vote on all questions, the same as men.

The Anti-Discrimination bill, as reported to the Assembly, was yesterday passed to a third reading by the encouraging vote of 73 to 33.

Grant. Whether or not this majority will represent the real sentiment of the Republicans of the State is a question.

PHILADELPHIA, April 9.--Recent developments in Philadelphia have done much to fix public attention upon election frauds and the imperative need of devising some method of checking existing evils.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--The House met at 7:30 o'clock this evening for the purpose of considering bills reported from the Committee on Naval Affairs. The first bill on the calendar was that providing a permanent construction fund for the Navy.

PARIS, April 14.--M. Leon Chotteau had an interview to-day with Premier de Frevcinet, and delivered to him a document setting forth that no action will be taken by the Congress of the United States respecting a treaty of commerce until France has made known her proposals on the subject.

The third and final performance this season of Verdi's "La Forza del Destino" was a decided improvement on the two previous representations, and as the opera is now tolerably well known, it was evidently better appreciated. The cast included the same artists as before.
ALBANY, April 14.--The Anti-Discrimination bill was taken up this morning in the Assembly as a special order.

WASHINGTON, April 14.--Senator Ben Hill is afflicted with a mental disorder that is the subject of comment among his Southern associates. His peculiar form of mania is described under the polite name of "intellectual communicativeness."
LONDON, April 14.--Lincolnshire, South, polled its votes for members of Parliament today. Cork County polled its votes yesterday, and the result will probably be declared to-day.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 14.--The last act in the great Southern railroad operations seems to have been made by young Victor Newcomb, to whom even the Cincinnati press of to-day accords victory. Such is the enthusiasm here that a public serenade and reception will be given Newcomb Saturday night.

MANCHESTER, N.J., April 15.--A report from Tom's River says that the great forest fire is spreading toward Tuckerton Beach, and that the residence and outhouses of Judge Jeffrey, one of the Lay Judges of the county, have been consumed by the fire. Judge Jeffrey's residence was on the banks of Tom's River, and was one of the handsomest mansions in Ocean County.

MECHANICSVILLE, N.Y., April 15.--No jury has yet been obtained in the Billings case. At the adjournment of the court to-night 94 jurors had been examined, of whom 16 had been accepted and 5 challenged by the people, leaving 11 in the box, which number is subject to challenge. There remains only 78 jurors to be drawn from, but should the panel be exhausted another panel will be drawn.

The Breimann-Paasch case, which has attracted so mush public attention, has at last reached a trial. The plaintiff, Caroline Breimann, sues Catharine Passch, a wealthy widow, to recover $20,000 for the loss of her husband, who, it is charged, was led to desert and neglect his wife by reason of the blandishments and wealth of the defendant. Breimann is a tailor, and resided in Poughkeepsie.

LONDON, April 16.--The Pall Mall Gazette this evening explains that yesterday's decrease of the bullion in the Bank of France was only apparent. The bank is the agent for Italy for the withdrawal of Italian silver from circulation. The sum of 65,000,000 francs of this currency, held by the bank, was yesterday credited to the Italian Government.

WASHINGTON, April 18.--Several bills concerning the trade dollar having been referred to the House Committee on Coinage, a substitute has been reported by that committee directing the Secretary of the Treasury to cause to be exchanged, at the Treasury and Sub-Treasuries, legal-tender silver dollars for trade dollars, at par; to recoin the trade dollars into legal-tender dollars, and to coin no more trade dollars.
