The full effect of some recent decisions of the Court of Appeals setting aside assessments on property for "improvements" is rapidly becoming manifest, and unless legislative action is speedily taken, it is feared that a large addition to the permanent debt of the Municipality will be the result.

WASHINGTON, April 17.--Thirty American whaling vessels became imprisoned in the ice in the Arctic Ocean in September, 1871. Seeing that there was no hope of saving either their vessels or their property on board, the masters held a meeting, and sent out a boat expedition to look for help.

An excursion was made yesterday to Long Beach by the Directors of the Long Beach Improvement Company, invited guests, and several members of leading New-York clubs. Long Beach is a stretch of white sand six miles and threequarters long, lying south of Hempstead Bay, and beyond Rockaway Beach.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 18.--Gen. De Chanzy, the French Ambassador, will take his usual vacation after the departure of the Emperor for Livadia, which is expected in about two weeks.

HONG KONG, March 23.--Miss Lai Sun, a Chinese lady educated in America, the daughter of a Tientsen officer, has married Capt. Anderson, of the Chinese gun-boat Kwashing. The ceremony was performed at Shanghai by the Dean of the English Cathedral.

SCRANTON, Penn., April 17.--The rapid growth of the Knights of Labor throughout the United States, and especially in Pennsylvania, has awakened considerable apprehension in the public mind concerning the true character of this secret organization, whose ramifications extend almost into every town and hamlet in 28 States of the Union.

CINCINNATI, April 19.--The auction sale of choice for seats for the entire season of the May festival concerts began to-day. The first choice sold for $100, but the premiums soon settled down to $10 and $5, and at the close to $2.

ALBANY, April 19.--The two houses of the Legislature reassembled this evening at the usual hour. The Democrats were conspicuous by their absence, there being only four in attendance in the Assembly, and three in the Senate.

GLOVERSVILLE, N.Y., April 19.--The Hon. Levi Parsons, of New-York City, a former resident of Kingsboro, Fulton County, N.Y., has given $50,000 to establish a public library for Gloversville and Kingsboro. The citizens have held a meeting, and voted to name it the "Parsons Library," and have promptly subscribed nearly $5,000 for a building lot.

CHICAGO, April 19.--A Galena (Ill.) special to the Times says Gen. Grant arrived there at 6 o'clock this evening. Many of the leading citizens were at the depot, but there was no public demonstration. He is looking very well, although much bronzed by his Southern tour.

The entertainment last night at Steinway Hall, which Signor Campanini gave for the benefit of the Italian school in Leonard-street, was a grand success in every respect. Both the large and small halls were filled with an audience that must have numbered almost 2,500 persons.

LEBANON, MO., April 19.--Sunday afternoon at 6 o'clock Springfield was visited by a heavy rain-storm, with hail and wind, but luckily escaped the heavier part of the storm, which passed six miles south of there, and, so far as yet heard from, had its origin in the western part of Greene County, six miles south of Springfield.

LONDON, April 6.--Not a vacant seat on the first night, nor since, at the Opera Comique. The pretty little house is crowded. All the places that can be booked ahead are secured. Mr. D'Oyly Carte, when he selected this house for English comic opera, exactly gauged its capacity.

CINCINNATI, April 19.--Mahoning County to-day elected Blaine delegates to the Republican State Convention. Of the 40 counties which have so far held conventions, Blaine has either a majority or a solid delegation from 9; Sherman has the remainder. CINCINNATI, April 20.--The auction sale of seats at the May Festival Concerts closed to-day. Nineteen hundred and forty-four seats have been sold, at the total premium of $6,377, which amount is nearly $700 greater than was realized two years ago.

CHICAGO, April 20.--Two of Chicago's wealthiest families were united to-night by the marriage of William Armour, son of George Armour, of Armour, Dole Co. heavy dealers in grain, to Miss Bertha M. Cobb, daughter of Silas M. Cobb, a widely-known capitalist.
ATLANTA, Ga., April 20.--The Republican State Convention which will meet here to-morrow, will be the most important body of the kind that has assembled since the party lost the control of the State.

LONDON, April 20.--The Liberal leaders have not attempted to make any arrangement about the Premiership. They await the Queen's summons. AUGUSTA, Ga., April 20.--The recent frosts in this part of Georgia and in South Carolina have not been so destructive to fruit and vegetables as was at first anticipated. Preparations are made for planting a larger acreage in cotton than usual.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., April 20.--Louis H. Cramer testified to-day in the Billings trial relative to making a survey and a map of Billings's premises. James H. Lloyd testified to photographing the residence, and Edward G. Cochrane testified to acting as clerk at the Coroner's inquest.

PARIS, April 20.--In his circular to the French representatives abroad, explanatory of the foreign policy pursued by him since his accession to office, Premier de Freycinet says he has no wish to change the policy which has prevailed for several years, and which is especially a policy of peace and conciliation.

C. W. Cook has been nominated for Congress by the Greenbackers of the Second District of Kentucky.

Seth B. Hunt, one of the oldest dry goods merchants of this City, died last evening at his home, No. 35 West Nineteenth-street, after a weeks illness. Mr. Hunt was born in Bennington, Vt., Feb. 12, 1811, his father being a farmer there.

WASHINGTON, April 20.--The Secretary of the Navy has received advices that the Trenton sailed from Villefranche April 3, and arrived at Naples the following day. She was expected to remain there a few days, and then proceed on a cruise to the coast of Egypt and the East.

CHICAGO, April 20.--A dispatch to the Tribune from Springfield, Ill., says: "The Sangamon County Democratic Convention met to-day and selected a delegation to the State Conventions, instructed to do all in its power to secure and instruct the State delegation to Cincinnati for Palmer.

CITY OF MEXICO, April 16.--President Diaz has granted a concession to Robert R. Symon, who represents a Boston company, for the construction of a railway to Leon with one branch to the Pacific coast and another to the Rio Grande. The concession is made subject to the approval of Congress.

PETERSBURG, VA., April 20.--The April term of the Dinwiddie County Court, Judge R. C. Shell presiding, was held yesterday. A special Grand Jury had been summoned to inquire into and if possible ferret out the lynchers of James Black.

CHICAGO, April 20.--It is reported to-night that the South-western Railway Association freight pool arrangements are creating dissatisfaction, which may result in rupture. The new system of tonnage gives no more satisfactory results than the old system of earnings did. Gould's roads are said to have cleared $100,000 under the new system, against $34,000 under the old one.

Charles Sacia, one of the most accomplished, daring, and successful confidence operators and forgers in the country, died in the Hudson County (N.J.) Church Hospital, in Magnolia-avenue, Jersey City Heights, yesterday.

BOSTON, April 20.--Miss Neilson appeared here this evening, at the Globe Theatre, in her charming impersonation of viola, before an immense audience. Last night she opened her engagement as Isabella, in "Measure for Measure," which had never before been produced in Boston.

WASHINGTON, April 20.--The House Committee on Ways and Means agreed to-day to report Mr. Johnston's bill to amend the statutes relative to the cancellation of export bonds on exportation of tobacco, snuff, and cigars.
WASHINGTON, April 20, 1880. The House amendments to the bill for an exhibition in New-York in 1883 were concurred in by the Senate to-day.

THE NEW-YORK TIMES, which is the best and handsomest, and altogether the most attractive daily newspaper in the United States, has come out in a new Spring suit of type, which gives it a fresh and rejuvenated appearance.

Charles Francis Adams, Jr., delivered a, lecture in Steinway Hall last evening before the Independent Republican Association of this City. When he commenced to speak the hall was about twothirds full. As he proceeded the audience grew small by degrees, and at the close of the lecture the hall was comparatively empty.

The 500 delegates to the Tammany State Convention returned to this City from Syracuse last evening, on board their special train, which rolled into the Grand Central Depot at a few minutes after 8 o'clock.
The grand salon of the Fifth-avenue Hotel was filled by ladies and gentlemen last evening on the occasion of the regular monthly reunion of the Goethe Club.
GALVESTON, April 21.--The Democratic State Convention organized yesterday, with Ashbel Smith as Chairman. Two hundred and seventy delegates were present, 50 counties being unrepresented.

WASHINGTON, April 21.--The bill for the distribution of the remainder of the money awarded by the arbitrators at Geneva was buried in the Senate to-day beyond hope of resurrection during this session of Congress. It cannot be supposed that its supporters expected that it would be successful, for the action of the Senate in the past had indicated to them its feelings on this question.

WEST POINT, April 21.--The examination of the members of the corps as to their knowledge of the outrage was continued to-day, 139 witneses in all being sworn.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 21.--The Licking County Republicans had their convention today at Newark. The Sherman men, led by the Hon. J.R. Stanberry, made a bolt and left the hall, after finding that they could not control the convention. A solid Blaine delegation to the State Convention was chosen. Excitement runs high, and it is quite probable that another set of delegates will be chosen by the Sherman bolters.

WASHINGTON, April 21.--In the House today, the Immediate Deficiency bill was withdrawn, after two hours had been spent in filibustering and in attempts to reach an agreement as to fixing the time for general debate.

THE TIMES a few months ago state that an effort was making to erect a suitable memorial stone over the grave of Joseph Gales, for 50 years the editor of the National Intelligencer. Unlike most enterprises of the kind, a very short time has sufficed to carry the project forward to success, and to-day the monument will be put in place.

LONDON, April 21.--A dispatch from Rome says: "Signor Giovanni Ferenzona, who was reported in these dispatches to have been assassinated, was a correspondent of the Gazetta d'Italia. He was stabbed at Leghorn by an unknown hand."
The feature of yesterday's cotton market was the sale of 5,200 bales direct for Russia, something entirely unusual.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., April 21.--A special from Marshfield to the Republican says: "Seventy-one victims of Sunday's storm have been buried, and about 25 or more are in a dying condition. The number seriously wounded is about 150.

MOBERLY, Mo., April 21.--A party of 40 men surrounded the jail here last night, where the three negro murderers, Henry Mitchell, "Dick" Yancey, and Alfred Caseon, were incarcerated, and demanded of the three officers who were keeping guard that the prisoners be delivered over to them.

SYRACUSE, April 21.--The conventions adjourned so late last night that very few of the delegates from a distance were able to leave town till to-day. The New-York delegation to the Kelly convention returned in a special train this morning, while most of the Tilden delegates left by different trains during the day.
A concert of Irish and Scottish music, songs and ballads, will take place to night at Steinway Hall.

ATLANTA, Ga., April 21.--The Republican Convention met at 10 o'clock, in the State Capitol, with a full representation. Double delegations were present from many counties. The feelings aroused in the caucuses the night previous were still alive and soon displayed themselves.

A meeting of clergymen of the Protestant Episcopal Church was held in the Sunday-school room of Trinity Chapel yesterday afternoon to express in appropriate resolutions their sense of their loss in the death of the Rev. Dr. Osgood.

LONDON, April 21.--It is reported that the Right Hon. Sir Fitzroy Kelly, the, Lord Chief Baron of the Exchequer, is to be created a Peer, and that Sir John Holker, Attorney-General, will succeed him as Chief Baron of the Exchequer.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--The resignation of Capt. Eugene B. Gibbs, Assistant Quartermaster, United States Army, of his commission as First Lieutenant, Sixth Infantry, has been accepted by the President, to take effect March 30.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--The bill regulating immigration to the United States, which was reported to the House by Chairman Cox, of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, was under consideration at a session held this evening. After Mr. Cox had spoken in support of the bill, the Hon. L.P. Morton, of New-York, made a strong speech on the same side of the question.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--Commissioner Raum has received a copy of an affidavit recently made by Deputy Collector John H. Stewart, of Fannin County, Ga., in regard to the recent outrage committed upon him and his family.

TRENTON, April 22.--Mrs. Elizabeth Schinkle, of Chambersburg, was instantly killed at noon today by being struck by a passenger train on the Bordentown Branch Railroad at the Crossstreet crossing. She was going with dinner to the rolling mill where her husband is employed. A Mrs. Warman, who was in her company, had a very narrow escape.
ATHENS, April 22.--The Greek Chamber of Deputies has passed the Army Reorganization bill, reducing the force from 17,000 to 12,000 men, and substituting volunteering for conscription.

The fifty-eighth anniversary of the formation of the Old Guard occurred yesterday, and it was the intention of its members to celebrate the occasion by an entertainment. Invitations had been extended to several other veteran organizations to be present, among them the "State Fencibles," of Philadelphia, and the "Citizens Corps," of Troy.
Mr. Locke, the author of "Widow Bedott," has written a new five-act comedy called "Quartz Valley."

MONTPELIER, Vt., April 23.--The Democratic State Convention assembled at Trinity Hall to-day. About 400 delegates were present. Hiram Atkins, Chairman of the State Committee, called the convention to order.

PARIS, April 22.--Mr. Slosson and M. Vignaux, the billiard-players, will play a match game, beginning on the 28th or 30th inst., and continuing five nights, 600 points to be played each night. The stake will be the same as was played for at the last game, corners to be barred after three shots.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate to-day: Edgar M. Marble of Michigan, to be Commissioner of Patents; Joseph K. McCamman, of Pennslvania, to be Assistant Attorney-General of the United States.

The Norwegian bark Sea Breeze, which arrived from Rotterdam yesterday, brought the entire crew of the brig Annie Wharton, bound from London for New-Haven, which was abandoned March 23, in latitude 41 , longitude 31 . Capt. Lawrence, of the lost brig, reports that on the 20th of March he was caught in a heavy north-easterly gale.

The twenty-seventh anniversary of the Wilson Industrial School for Girls was held yesterday in the mission building, Avenue A and St. Mark'splace. After some interesting songs and recitations had been listened to from the children in the large hall, the latter were addressed by the Rev. Dr. C. D'W. Bridgeman.

Sheriff Toffey, of Hudson County, yesterday received a letter from the Chief of Police of Trenton informing him that the bogus widow, Lewis, had escaped beyond the reach of the Hudson County authorities.

The following business was transacted by the Court of Appeals yesterday: No. 177--Jane M. Van Brunt, respondent, vs. Edward P. Day, appellant; argued by S.C. Conable for appellant, W.S. Cogswell for respondent.

WASHINGTON, April 22.--The Congressional Record of to-day shows to what extremes may be carried the bad practice which prevails in the House of allowing members to print, with the account of the regular proceedings, speeches which are never delivered in the House or anywhere else.

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 22.--The Supreme Court has had before it a case from Jasper County, wherein a Greenbacker and an Anti-Monopolist agreed to take a county office for less than the legal salary, and to return the surplus to the county if elected. The decision was that the election was void and the proffer a bribery of the voters.

SYRACUSE, April 22.--The first effects this season of past Democratic canal management were felt on the Eastern Division of the Erie Canal to-day. A disastrous break occurred near the guard lock at West Utica at 4 o'clock this morning.

SOMERVILLE, N.J., April 21.--The April Term of the Somerset County Circuit Court opened Tuesday morning. Judge Magie presided. The first case on the calendar is that of the County against Daniel Cory, to recover money wrongfully appropriated by him as Freeholder. MERIDIAN, Miss., April 26.--A heavy storm passed over Macon, Miss., last night, blowing away 22 houses, including the Mobile and Ohio Railroad machine shops, round-house, depot, telegraph office, and master mechanic's office. Sixteen cars were blown from the track, and 17 persons were killed and 22 wounded.

The "College Club," of St. Louis College, No. 104 West Thirty-eighth-street, will give their eleventh annual dramatic entertainment in the Union League Theatre Thursday evening next.

MADISON, Wis., April 26.--Edwin Alme, H. Silvester, and A.B. Halverson, while partly intoxicated, yesterday visited an Indian encampment near McFarland, in this county. They engaged in a row with the Indians, during which an Indian child, 4 years old, was kicked to death. The whole party was arrested last night. Silvester is charged with killing the child.

In his second lecture on dogs at the Royal Institution, in London, Prof. Huxley considered the problem of the origin of the domestic dog. CINCINNATI, May 1.--Crop reports from Ohio, Indiana, Southern Illinois, and Kentucky are of the most favorable character. The wheat crop in this region wintered almost without injury, and is everywhere far advanced and in splendid condition. The acreage is from 20 to 30 per cent. greater than last year, which was itself a big year.

The funeral of Patrick Hoy, better known as James Cooke, the clown and equestrian, late of Sarnum's great show, was held yesterday afternoon. When Mr. Cooke knew that he was about to die he was asked by the priest who attended him to renounce the principles of Masonry, to which he had been ardently attached from his boyhood.

In accordance with a custom which they have kept up for several years, the Germans of Paterson, N.J., yesterday repaired to the summit of Garret Mountain, the highest peak near the city, to greet the rising of the sun on the first Sunday in May. The custom is one which they have brought from "Fatherland," where it has been observed from time immemorial.

ERWINNA, Penn., May 1.--It was discovered, several weeks ago, that "Rattlesnake Pete," whose cabin and odd manner of life have already been described in THE TIMES, had disappeared. His fire, which always burned at night and lighted up the woods with fantastic shapes, was unkindled, and no traces of Pete himself were discernible.

A German military writer of eminence has lately drawn a parallel between Caius Marius and Ulysses Simpson Grant. The Roman soldier, who died just 19 centuries ago, presents undoubtedly many features of character and many points of resemblance which justify an analytical comparison between him and the American soldier who, in a higher degree than any of his compatriots, crushed the most formidable rebellion of which history bears record.

Almost the entire afternoon was taken up yesterday by the Committee of Eleven and the Trustees of the Western University in discussing the recent troubles at that institution and the means for improving its condition. The Committee of Eleven recommended numerous changes in the curriculum, an average reduction of $200 in the salaries of membere of the Faculty, and the reduetion of their number. After some discussion the report was adopted.

A recent circular of the Greman Minister of War has exhorted Colonels to urge their subalterns toward the study of modern languages. An advantage which the German Army--or at least the Prussian section of it--has over the armies of other countries is that studious habits are the rule rather than the exception among officers, because it is known that proficiency in any branch of knowledge whatsoever is almost sure to bring its recompense.

Within the last five weeks no less than six steamers have been in collision with ice in the North Atlantic. Two of them were so badly injured that they were abandoned, and the other four reached port with their forward compartments full of water.

NEW-ORLEANS, May 2.--Dr. Samuel Choppin, the distinguished surgeon, died of pneumonia at 8 o'clock this evening after three days' illness. Dr. Chofpin was born in West Baton Rouge, La., Oct. 20, 1828, and was the son of Paul and Eliza Choppin.

MILFORD, Penn., May 2.--Under the Game law of Pennsylvania the trout-fishing season opens on the lst day of April, except in Pike County, where the 1st of May is the opening day. Owing to the very favorable conditions that prevailed during the Winter, the beginning of the present season in this county was awaited with more than usual interest.
The Master Mason's degree will be conferred at the communication of Montgomery Lodge, No. 68, F. and A.M., to be held in the Masonic Temple this evening.

GENTLEMEN: After a service of nearly 30 years with the company, I find it necessary to tender my resignation as its President and as one of its Directors, to take effect June 1. I do this only because I am assured by my physician that it is indispensable to a possible restoration of my health that I should be relieved from the cares and responsibilities inseparable from the position.

ROME, May 2.--The King has signed a decree dissolving the Chamber of Deputies. Elections will be held on May 18, and the new Chamber will meet on May 28.

Jupiter is morning star, and by far the most important object for observation among the planets during the month. It cannot be too strongly impressed upon the minds of students of the stars, that the four great planets are all approaching their perihelia, and bringing about a condition of planetary affairs that has not occrred for 2,000 years, Jupiter reaches the goal first, arriving at perihelion on the 25th of September.

SPANISH EGGS.--Cook one cup of rice 30 minutes in two quarts of boiling water to which has been added one tablespoonful of salt; drain through a colander, and then add one tablespoonful of butter. Spread on a hot platter very lightly. Now on the rice place six dropped eggs, and serve.

NORTH ADAMS, Mass., May 8.--A horse and carriage owned by a liveryman, Mr. Clark, of Troy, N.Y., was stolen on May 4. To-day the thief was captured here, and the property was recovered in Greenfield, where it had been sold for an old watch and several worthless promissory notes. The thief gives the name of William B. Hastings, and makes a full confession. He will be examined Monday.

Fulton Market has finally been decided by inspectors of the Department of Buildings to be in an unsafe condition, and dangerous to the limbs and lives of its occupants and of the persons who pass through it. CAMBRIDGE, May 7.--Twenty-eight years ago next August the first intercollegiate boat-race between Yale and Harvard was rowed. Yale gave the challenge. WASHINGTON, May 8, 1880. A bill was introduced to-day by Mr. Hooker, of Mississippi, from the Committee on Indian Affairs, transferring the office of Indian Affairs from the Interior to the War Department. It was placed on the House calendar.

The Supreme Court of Georgia has destroyed the last hope of Edward COX, the murderer, it having refused, by a unanimous vote, to grant his request for a mandamus to compel the reopening of his case. There is now no escape for him from undergoing his sentence of imprisonment for life, unless the Executive pardon should intervene, and this is said to be extremely unlikely to happen.

TOLEDO, Ohio, May 10.--At a special meeting of the Produce Exchange here to-day the Hon. Frank Kurd explained the purpose and effect of his bill now pending in Congress to regulate international transportation. He showed that its passage would be highly beneficial to American manufacturers generally, and would especially benefit the traffic of Toledo.

ALBANY, May 11.--After neglecting the Public Burdens bills, as they are called, for three months, the Assembly passed them this morning, the Demorcats and a few Republicans who are bound by special interests offering a feeble resistance.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--The House to-day decided the Yocum-Cumin contested election case in favor of Mr. Yocum, the sitting member, by a majority of 38. The majority of the Committee on Elections reported that in consequence of gross irregularities neither Yocum nor Curtin was legally elected, and recommended that a new election be held by the people of the district.

When the fourth annual bench show was opened to the public, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, very few of the animals entered were absent from their stalls, and among these the only ones of importance were the St. Louis Kennel Club's string. The attendance throughout the day, particularly in the evening, was as large as on any first day ever known.

GRANVILLE, N. J., May 11.-Adelaide Crawford, Simeon Crawford's daughter, 7 years old, was fatally burned, last night, by the explosion of a kerosene-oil lamp in her bedroom during the absence of her parents, She died to-day.

WASHINGTON, May 11.--Capt. W. H. Heuer, Corps of Engineers, in addition to his present duties, has been assigned to the duties connected with the jetties at the South Pass of the Mississippi River, with which the late Capt. M. R. Brown, Corps of Engineers, was charged. Capt. Heuer will report to, and receive instructions from, the Chief of Engineers. The leave of absence granted

LONDON, May 11.-A Vienna dispatch says that 4,000 horses, 6,000 Martini rifles, and 130,000 cartridges have lately arrived at Scutari for the use of the Albanians, who now occupy the whole territory from Scntari and Prisrend to Kavaja. Turlash officers and men are everywhere fraternizing with them.

The annual meeting of the Mercantile Library association was held last evening in Clinton Hall, and was rendered decidedly lively by an attempt to amend the constitution in respect to the election of the Board of Directors. Mr. W.D. Searls presided, and Mr. S. Putnam acted as Secretary.

A good illustration of the facility with which ultra State rights men change their views when selfish considerations intervene is found in Democratic support of a bill to authorize the United States Geological Survey to extend its work into the different States of the Union.

The seventy-fourth anniversary of the NewYork Orphan Asylum, at Seventy-third-street, near the Boulevard, was celebrated yesterday, the exercises commencing at 2:30 P. M. The building and grounds are in excellent condition, and the boys and girls are all ruddy, healthy, and happy.

The hearing in the contest over the late Frank Leslie's will was continued before Surrogate Calvin yesterday. Testimony was adduced from a number of witnesses to show the influence wielded by Mrs. Leslie over the actions of Mr. Leslie, and also to show the indications of unsoundness of mind in the decedent. J. Howard Browne, of the American News Company, testified that he was in the employ of Frank Leslie from 1873 to 1877.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., May 11.--The lawsuit brought by Pike County, Penn., against Benjamin H. Rose and James W. Quick, late Treasurer of the county, is now being tried at Honesdale, Wayne County, the proceedings having been cited to that county by the defendants' counsel to escape alleged prejudice in Pike County. The circumstances connected with this suit, and the incidents which it recalls, are of more than local interest.

LONDON, May 11.-The Morning Post says: "It is quite unprecedented to have to place before the public two such documents as the letters of Mr. Fawcett and Mr. Gladstone. Two wills, both of which were made by former hotel proprietors, were offered for probate before Surrogate Calvin yesterday. One was the testament of George Ross, formerly proprietor of the Rossmore Hotel. He left his entire estate, amounting to about $1,000,000, to his family.

Cornell in the early part of last month, by the Judiciary Committee of the Bar Association. Gov. Cornell informed Judge Sinnott of the character of the charges, and he denied their truth upon "the sanctity of his official oath."

WINSLOW, N. J., day 11.-In a quarrel which occurred at a political meeting near Shark's Mills last evening, a young man named W. J. Shanifield was fatally stabbed, and another young man named Gardner so badly beaten that his life is despaired of. The perpetrators as yet are unknown to the Police.
Signor Italo Campanini, the great tenor, yesterday visited Pietro Balbo in the City Prison. An Italian Navy commander also visited the young prisoner.

ALBANY, May 11--The Senate did one thing to-day which, in the minds of many people, will mark an era, in the history of New-York legislation. It passed, by a vote of 17 to 14, Mr. Halbert's resolution for an amendment to the Constitution, permitting women to vote at all elections and on all questions, the same as men.

The few contestants for positions on the Irish Team who visited Creedmoor yesterday were favored with one of the steadiest winds that has blown across the range this season. About noon a heavy shower came up. It resulted only in the postponement of the shooting for about an hour, while it not only cooled the atmosphere, but calmed the breeze which had been blowing across the range before.

LONDON, May 13.--A large proportion of the factory operatives of Blackburn left their work yesterday as they finished the making up. It is, however, doubtful whether, in the end, the strike will become general, as public opinion is altogether opposed to it.

WASHINGTON, May 13.-By direction of the Secretary of War, Surgeon J.J. Woodward will proceed to Europe under special instructions to be communicated by the Surgeon-General of the Army. After the completion of the duties assigned him, Surgeon Woodward will return to his station in this city.

The Sauba auts are very destructive to the sugar-cane in Brazil. A process has been introduced for the purpose of destroying these pests, and it has proved of considerable success. There are numerous commentaries, treatises, , by the recognized authorities of this country and England, but most of them are not the latest editions.

Six European steam-ships, the Mosel, of the North German Lloyd; the city of Richmond, of the Inman Line; the Circassia, of the Anchor Line; the Canada, of the National Line; the Nederland, of the Red Star Line, and the Patagonia, of the White Star Line, will sail for Europe to-day, with an aggregate of about 400 cabin passengers.

Aside from the obvious heartlessness of administering upon a man's estate before he has shuffled off this mortal coil, there is an element of the grotesque in the eagerness of the Democratic leaders to become the political legatees of Mr. TILDEN. WASHINGTON, May 21.--The Sundry Civil Appropriation bill for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1881, was reported to the House just before its adjournment this afternoon. It recommends an aggregate appropriation of $20,729,987. The estimates submitted to the committee aggregated $24,374,026.41. The present bill exceeds the amount appropriated for 1880 by $1,255,953.49.

Col. J.M. Briton was recalled by the Warren Court of Inquiry yesterday, and gave the time when Gen. Sheridan devolved the command of the Fifth Corps upon Gen. Griffin as about 5 o'clock in the afternoon. The enemy's works had just been captured.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 21.--In the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day, reports of the Committees on Foreign and Domestic Missions, Education, Publication, Theological Seminaries, and the Institute for the Education of Colored Ministers at Tuscaloosa, disclosing a gratifying condition of the Church, were read.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 22.--There are many and growing indications that the South will assert her full power at the Cincinnati Convention. "Our passive compliance," said an influential Democrat to-day, "with everything our Northern and western allies said and did has been misconstrued into cowardice by some and indifference by others, and we are not willing to occupy such an anomalous position.

CHARLESTON, S.C., May 22.--In the Presbyterian General Assembly to-day, the Trustees reported $34,000 in hand, belonging to the relief fund. Some 15 of the boarders in Mrs. Alcott's boarding-house, No. 179 Remsen-street, Brooklyn, partook of lemon meringue pie for dessert, on Friday evening. Four or five hours afterward all of them were taken sick, and in every case the symptoms were the same.

COPENHAGEN, May 3.--I have got out of England not a whit too soon, for the warmth of April has been followed by the cold of May. Moreover, however glorious the "Liberal victory" may have been, yet when you know by fatal experience that every man whom you see approaching is going to talk of nothing else for half an hour, it becomes (as the English tourist said of the yellow fever,) "somewhat monotonous by repetition."

Divorce is, on the best grounds, so serious in itself and so painful in its associations that any sensitive person who may feel obliged to seek it must always deeply regret the obligation. Divorce, too, almost invariably causes scandal, and scandal mars the serenest selfcontent.

There was a large gathering yesterday afternoon at the Society of Arts, to hear a lecture by Dr. B.W. Richardson on Mr. Fleuss's new diving apparatus. In the first part of his lecture Dr. Richardson sketched the history of diving apparatus from 1664. He then explained Mr. Fleuss's diving-dress.

PARIS, May 7.--That most eloquent and once most popular preacher, known in by-gone days as Father Hyacinthe, and none as M. Loyson, is in trouble. Trouble and vexation of spirit, indeed, seem to have been his chronic condition since he went into the neo-Catholic business, and exchanged for an ordinary black coat the flowing white robes which used to lend a sort of dignity to his rather vulgar face and pudgy person.

BERLIN, May 22.--An identical note from the powers will go to Constantinople in a few days summoning the Porte to settle the Armenian, Montenegrin, and Greek questions. Upon the reply of the Porte will depend whether a supplementary conference will be held in Berlin to consider the Greek question.

The second elevens of the St. George's and the Staten Island Cricket Clubs played an interesting match yesterday on the Camp Washington Grounds, near Tompkinsville, Staten Island. The opening of the game was marked by cautious batting on the part of J. Hyde Clarke and P.O. Westfeldt, of the St. George's, against the bowling of Maning and Rich.

WASHINGTON, May 22.--When the morning hour expired in the Senate to-day, Mr. Morgan, of Alabama, spoke in support of the resolution for a joint resolution for counting the Electoral vote. COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 22.--The action of the Springfield Convention has been watched with eager interest by the Ohio politicians, who, up to the last moment, had believed that Senator Blaine would secure the Illinois delegation.
PLYMOUTH, Mass., May 22.--Gunn, the Bridgewater murderer, cut his throat to-day with a razor borrowed from one of the inmates of the House of Correction. The wound is probably not fatal.

Strawberries are in liberal supply, and prices are lower. The quality of the fruit received is poor, nothing like as good as it may be in about a month, when we will have a supply from New-Jersey and this State. The dry weather prevailing down South causes the berries to ripen prematurely. The best fruit in the market comes from Maryland. Cherries are in moderate supply from North Carolina. They are poor and cheap.

There was an extraordinary series of incendiary fires in Bergen County, N.J., along the eastern shore of the Passaic River, opposite Paterson, on Friday night. John Hopper is a well-to-do farmer near the Fifth-avenue bridge. A few minutes before 12 o'clock a tongue of fire shot up from one of his barns, and speedily the whole building was in a blaze.

VIENNA, April 28.--The grand carrousel or hunting pageant which the Austro-Hungarian nobles have just given for the benefit of the sufferers in the provinces, was an affair of rare brilliancy--a magnificent spectacle, in which real lords and ladies were the actors, gorgeously attired in the costliest materials, sparkling with costly jewels, mounted on splendid chargers, bearing the weapons of illustrious ancestors, and moving with the dignity and grace of inherited and studied excellence.

In the severe strain to which Christian belief is now subjected, it is not surprising that there is a visible, if not notable, increase of those who hold agnostic views. The question before every one is, whether Christianity is anything more than one of the many forms in which the heart and mind of man have found an expression of what is best.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 22.--The enthusiasm of the college is at present gathered around the ball nine. It is nearly five years since the students had as good reason to be proud of their nine as they have this year. The record so far this season is an exceptionally brilliant one--a continued series of victories, ending with the signal defeat of Harvard yesterday, is credited to their account.

LONDON, May 15.--Several American and a dozen foreign artists have found favor in the eyes of Sir Coutts Lindsay and his counsel and been admitted to the Grosvenor Gallery. Among the former, Augustus Saint Gaudens, of New-York, and among the latter Bastien Le Page, of Paris, may be said to carry off the honors for sculpture and painting, respectively.

The American Medical Association will hold its thirty-first annual meeting in this City, beginning at 10 A. M. to-morrow and closing on Thursday afternoon. The sessions of the main body will be in Association Hall, although some of the sections will meet in the building of the College of Physicians and Surgeons. Between 1,400 and 1,500 delegates are expected to be present.

LONDON, June 3.--Sir Alexander T. Galt, the Canadian Minister here, was given a banquet last night by the Canada Club. HARTFORD, Conn., June 4.--On the night of April 5, a train on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Road, with half the embankment, slid off into a peat bog, about two miles from Meriden. Its serious result will probably be a lesson long remembered.

WASHINGTON, June 4.--The excitement in Washington to-night over the proceedings of the Chicago Convention is almost equal to that exhibited on the night following the last Presidential election. Cyprien M. TessiE Du Motay, a celebrated French inventor and chemist, died suddenly of cerebral congestion yesterday at his residence, No. 13 West Twenty-sixth-street, aged about 65 years. M. Du Motay was born in Brittany, of an old and aristocratic family of that name.

DINGMAN'S FERRY, Penn., June 5.--Austin Sheldon, who has occupied a rocky cave in the forests of Lehman Township, Pike County, Penn., seven miles from this place, for more than 30 years, living without a companion of any kind, has become tired of leading a single life, and recently became enamored of a girl yet in her teens, who resides within a few miles of the hermit's abode.

WEST POINT, June 6.--The main subject of interest at the Military Academy still continues to be the shooting of young Thompson, by Buck, at Highland Falls, on Friday morning, but no new developments have occurred to-day. Buck is confined in jail at Newburg, and, by advice of his counsel, refuse to talk, so that his side of the story, if he really has a side to tell, cannot be made public.

PHILADELPHIA, June 9.--For 12 or 15 years Philadelphia has been the seat of a number of medical colleges that flooded the country with bogus diplomas. The authorities declared themselves powerless to stop it.

TRENTON, June 12.--A tornado passed over the City of Trenton at 2 o'clock this afternoon, from the north, destroying sheds, trees, and unfinished buildings. Twenty-four French-speaking societies began to celebrate, at Jones's Wood Colosseum, yesterday, a festival in honor of the establishment of the French Republic. ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 5.--Canandaigua, a beautiful village 40 miles east of this place, on the Auburn branch of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad, will be very much startled by a social sensation tomorrow morning.

John Orr, a mechanic, of No. 531 Burgessstreet, Kensington, started out early yesterday morning to give his children an airing on the river. A row-boat was almost filled with the Pour children, Kate Marks, his sister-in-law, aged 22, and Robert Ritchie, a boy who went along to represent the owner of the boat. They fished and paddled about the river all day, and soon after sundown directed their craft toward home.

POUGHKEEPSIE, July 6.--It was only a brief dispatch that told of a terrible accident on the draw-bridge on the Hudson River Railroad track, near Dutchess Junction, yesterday morning. Little Bella Crismier was the daughter of Mary Jane Williams by a former husband. She was 6 years of age.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 6.--The steamer R. D. Cazenove, with 100 Syracuse pleasure-seekers, was sunk in Cazenovia Lake. No lives were lost.

SARATOGA, July 7.--At the morning session of the American Institute of Instruction, the Hon. Neil Gilmour, Superintendent of Public Instruction of New-York, made a brief address, welcoming the institute to the State. The President of the institute responded. A letter was also read from Gov. Cornell, regretting his inability to attend the meeting owing to prior engagements.

Jacob Kuntz, a farmer, at Homestead Station, in the upper section of Hudson County, N. J., shot his wife, Anne Maria, at Union Hill yesterday morning, fatally injuring her, and then blew his own brains out. Kuntz and his wife were both advanced in years. For the last 20 years they have-lived unhappily.

LONDON, July 7.--This morning's Post says: "The Speaker of the House of Commons has informed Mr. Bradlaugh that it was no breach of privilege to serve a member with a writ within the precincts of Westminster Palace. Another writ was served on Mr. Bradlaugh yesterday."

The grand Garfield and Arthur ratification meeting in the Jersey City Academy of Music last evening drew a crowd that filled the building to overflowing. It was a highly respectable gathering, a good proportion being ladies. The Academy is not well ventilated, and last night it was a veritable sweat-box.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 8.--Mr. Hespeler, the Immigration Agent at this point, states that there are now arriving in this country a very desirable class of emigrants, principally Scotch and English, many of them with sufficient money to settle upon farms and begin the cultivation of the soil. QUEBEC, July 8.--The salmon drought continues. And this is saying that one of the most important factors in the trade of the Provinces is seriously affected. To-morrow there will be a very liberal supply of Antwerp raspberries in the markets, but not so many as last Tuesday. BOSTON, July 9.--In Massachusetts, the Republicans and Independents being so generally united on the national ticket, and the State campaign being for once so refreshingly free from distracting local issues that an old-time majority, secured with comparatively little effort, is looked for, the canvass in the Congressional districts will demand the most attention.

Mr. Beecher preached his farewell sermon --the last before his annual trip to the White Mountains--yesterday. If he was suffering from "hay fever" he showed no sign of it in his face, which never looked ruddier or more healthful. He smiled benevolently as he climbed into his place between the two rosebushes that flanked the platform, and gave out a text that bore no especial reference to what followed.

TAPPAN, N.Y., July 14.--A heavy gloom rests upon this little village to-day in consequence of the horrible murder of Miss Hannah M. Brower, in a house near by, early on Tuesday morning. The murder and all the circumstances in connection with it form the only theme of conversation her now, and it seems that every man and woman in this vicinity feels almost as if the affliction was in his or her own household.

Baron Joseph J. Van den Wyngaert, of Berlin, returned from a trip on the Northern Pacific Railroad yesterday morning, and took his departure for Milwaukee at noon. The Baron, who is the President of the German Millers' Association, visits the United States at the request of the German Government to inspect the various wheat-growing sections and to examine the modes of milling.

The Republican State Executive Committee organized yesterday by electing the Hon. Thomas C. Platt Chairman, and made preparations for entering speedily upon an active campaign in this State. The members of the committee who were present came from widelyseparated sections of the State, and were fresh from contact with the working members of the Republican Party.

LONDON, July 14.--Sir Henry Halford has received a telegram from Col. Gildersleeve stating that the restriction refers to the American team as a body, not to the action of individual members.

LONDON, July 14.--This was the second day of the Liverpool July meeting. The race for the Liverpool Cup came off, and was won by Mr. Jardin's 4-year-old b.c. Blackthorn. The second place was secured by Mr. Whittaker's 3-year-old br. c. Lindrick, and the third place by Mr. Cameron's 5-year-old ch. h. Misenus.

An accident that resulted in the injuring of a score or more of Italian laborers happened at East Rockaway, on the Long Beach branch of the Long Island Railroad, yesterday. The men were thrown from the cars of a gravel-train by a derrick rope that stretched across the track, and some of them were very seriously, if not fatally, hurt.

LOWVILLE, N.Y., July 14.--Just as the Merrihew trial was about to begin this morning, before Judge Haight, of Buffalo, who had been appointed by Gov. Cornell to try the case, ex-Senator Turner, counsel for the prisoner, much to the surprise of everybody, asked that the case be put over.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 14.--Burglars entered the Summer residence of Augustus H. Havemeyer, at New-Windsor, last night and escaped with $200 worth of silverware. The residence of Miss Mary E. Miller was also visited, where the theives broke into the house, but were frightened away by the gardener before securing any plunder.
"No clue to the murderer yet," says the Galveston (Texas) News. But what is the use of getting a clue to a murderer in Texas?

The Paris correspondent of the Pall-Mall Gazette, writing of the scenes which accompanied the expulsion of the Jesuits, says: "Popular sympathy has been against the Jesuits in Paris, and it has been nowhere for them. In the Ardeche, Puyde-Dome, and Brittany crowds assembled at drawn to see the execution of the decrees, but gave no sign of friendly feeling. They went as they would have gone to witness the last act of an assize-court drama.

SCHENECTADY, July 14.--For some time past the Hon. John. H. Starin, who has so ably represented this district in Congress, has by his many friends been pressed to accept a renomination. For numerous good personal reasons, he has refused to do so. To-morrow the Schenectady Union will print the following letter in regard to the matter:

LONDON, July 14.--A dispatch from Pesth says: "A bill passed by the Bulgarian National Assembly, respecting the creation of a Bulgarian National Guard, contains provisions by which the whole military power would virtually rest with the Central Committee, under the immediate command of a Vice-President, drawing a salary of 7,000 francs if a Bulgarian and 14,000 francs if a foreigner.

LONDON, July 14.--A Berlin dispatch says: "American enterprise is beginning to turn the immense natural resources of Russia to account. Mr. Barker, the American who procured the first four cruisers of the Russian volunteer fleet when war with England was apprehended, has established a joint-stock company with a capital of $8,000,000 to work the South Russian coal mines.

The Democratic politicians, who have made the Fifth-Avenue Hotel and the Hoffman House their lounging-places for two or three days, have worried through some of the preliminary work of their campaign, and will now go home to contrive how they shall carry out their plans.

Having lightened the labors of Tuesday with a little diversion on Governor's Island, the Democratic visiting statesmen enjoyed themselves so well that they yesterday turned their steps with alacrity toward the residence of ex-Gov. Samuel J. Tilden, No. 15 Gramercy Park, for the purpose, as they said, of communicating to the "great defeated," in an official manner, the views of the National Convention with regard to his course since 1876.

Clarendon Hall, in East Thirteenth-street, is now the recognized centre of attraction for the medical fraternity of this City, and the Minneapolis man who is engaged in the prolonged fast is studied with ever-increasing astonishment as the days roll by.
WASHINGTON, July 14.--The following telegrams have been received at the War Department:

ALBANY, July 14.--At the meeting of the University Convocation, to-day, the attendance was much larger than yesterday. The first paper was read by Prof. Patrick A. Halpin, S.J., of St. John's College, on "Rhetoric and its Methods." He argued in favor of greater attention being given to the subject in our schools.

LAKE GEORGE, July 14.--A strong north wind prevailed throughout the morning, making the water unfit for shell rowing, and at one time it was feared that the junior sculling trial heats and the pair-oared race would not occur this afternoon. There is great excitement here relative to the college four-oared race, which will be rowed on Friday.

The anniversary of the taking of the Bastile was celebrated yesterday on board the French frigate Magicienne and her consort, Dumont d'Urville, which lie in the North River, opposite Pier No. 8, by a grand fete, in which officers and men participated. At sunrise both vessels were gayly decked in flags, and bunting was attached to every available point of the yards and rigging.

The Japanese naval training-ship Tsukuba, Capt. Ainaura, six days from Esquimalt, arrived in the bay yesterday forenoon, and came to anchor off the Vallejo-street wharf. The Tsukuba was here about six years ago, and was then the Malacca. The Tsukuba, which is one of a class of four training-ships belonging to the Japanese Navy, left Yeddo Bay on the 29th of April, bound on a cruise of instruction in the Pacific Ocean.

ALBANY, July 14.--The Controller's office is much exercised over the provisions of the act (chapter 542) to provide for raising taxes for the use of the State upon certain corporations, joint stock companies, and associations, which was signed by the Governor and became a law on June 1.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 14.--The reception to the Hon. Albert G. Porter this afternoon and evening was an event of unprecedented enthusiasm in Indianapolis. The special train from Columbus reached this city at 4 o'clock, and was greeted by not less than 2,000 people at the union depot. On the way hither at every large town there was an audience and a brief speech.

LONDON, July 14.--The Pall Mall Gazette says: "The line of policy announced by Mr. Parnell and his 17 supporters to, move to report progress when the Compensation for Disturbance in Ireland bill is again discussed, evidently leads to indefinite obstruction.

This is the thirty-fourth anniversary of the hoisting of the American flag at Monterey as the symbol of the establishment of American authority over California and Nevada. The Cabinet at Washington had intended for years to obtain possession of San Francisco Bay, and of the coast to the northward, and for years had employed Thomas O. Larkin in preparing the people, who were dissatisfied with Mexican rule, for a change.

A work that is to confer some distinction on this city is well under way on East-avenue, where the Warner Observatory is rapidly taking form, every movement being watched carefully by Dr. Swift, who is to be the presiding genius of the observatory. Work on the pier to hold up the telescope began Monday, Christian Stein having the contract for the entire observatory.

LONDON, July 14.--A Paris dispatch of Tuesday night says: "This evening the illuminations of the Cathedral of Notre Dame were tested in preparation for tomorrow evening. The whole building has been overspread with electric lamps, concealed in such a way as to throw their light upon the cathedral without the spectators observing its source.

FORT SUMNER, New-Mexico, July 1.--An enterprising and very rich company has now more than 200 miles of railway in full operation in New-Mexico. A rival company is pushing with speed the building of its roadway from the border of Colorado southward in the direction of Albuquerque.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 14.--The present crisis in the growth of the wheat crop has apparently passed, though the next 10 days will be full of possibilities of danger. For two days the weather has been moderately cool, with bright sun and brisk, drying winds, the reverse of the warm, damp, murky weather that caused so much alarm before. Reports from all over the State are all of a more hopeful character.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 15.--The Republicans of Luzerne County held their convention in Wilkesbarre to-day to make nominations for Congress, State Senator, and county offices. INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 15.--R.L. Hunt, of Missouri, was elected permanent President, and T. McNamara Secretary of the Irish Republican Convention to-day. A National Exexutive Committee was appointed, consisting of one member from each State and Territory.

DUBLIN, July 3.--If matters continue much longer on the "ounce of lead " lines, the Irish land question may be "settled" in detail, with results somewhat similar to those recorded in the case of the historic Kilkenny cats.

It is just 10 o'clock when we enter our carriage, the Vesuvius. We are five in each compartment, which can contain six. Horn signals are exchanged with the upper station and the signalstations, of which there are two along the line; a whistle is sounded, and we begin the ascent.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., July 15.--The recent rains have revived the hopes of the farmers throughout Central New-Jersey, and the prospects for good crops are considered excellent. The corn-fields present a fine picture today, the stalks having grown wonderfully within three days.

There will be music at Prospect Park to-morrow afternoon. The body of a man about 25 years of age, 5 feet 6 inches in height, with smooth face and sandy hair, was found floating in the Atlantic Basin yesterday. The remains were taken to the Morgue.

TROY, N.Y., July 15.--An accident occurred this morning at 3 o'clock, on the Troy and Boston track, at the upper end of Lansingburg. As a down freight train, consisting of 43 cars, was running down the sloping grade an axle of one of the forward cars broke, throwing the train from the track. Twentyfour cars left the track and 13 were wrecked...

LONDON, July 15.--A Constantinople dispatch says: "Diplomatists and financiers here are somewhat surprised at the sudden appearance of a number of German officers, recommended by the German Cabinet, to undertake a radical reform of Turkish finances.
